Was suppose to get the dorayaki ice cream for desert from our combo, but they said they ran out and didn't bother to give us options to choose something else and just gave us the cheap smores which was a little irritating. The only thing that I found that was pretty good was the lady m green tea crepe cake. Overall, wouldn't go out of my way to eat here

22.description: Great atmosphere and service!!! I loved how we ordered a lot of food but wasn't overly stuffed since we had to cook it while we digested. I must go again when I visit Chicago again.

15.description: I was searching for the perfect place to celebrate my birthday with a big group of friends, and Gyu Kaku did not disappoint. Gyu was like a combination of a Korean BBQ house and a Japanese izakaya. They pretty much took elements from two of my favorite types of restaurants so I was super excited to try it. I'm usually a value guy and aim to get my money's worth when it comes to Korean BBQ. Pretty much every good AYCE kBBQ restaurant I've been to has been some sort of no frills joint with non-English menus, and my sole purpose in life was to cram as much meat into my stomach until I could barely breathe. While that still sounds like a great meal, Gyu Kaku offers a different type of experience that balances good food but also a fun environment.Reservations: It didn't start out too well because if you try to reserve a table for more than 10 people, they pretty much force you to get one of their group packages. It didn't make sense for us though because there were various dietary restrictions within my group, and it would've been way easier to just order everything a la carte. That, and we didn't wanna waste any of our appetite on crap filler items like seaweed soups and salads. To be honest they were pretty inflexible about making substitutions and made planning this dinner way too difficult. They pretty much forced me to break my group into 2 separate tables and then told us they can't even try to get the two tables on the same floor. Ambiance: They had trendy decor that you'd find in a lot of these more modern Japanese restaurants. The first floor had a mix of booths and regular tables. The second floor had more regular tables and also a bar, and the third floor had traditional style seating where you take your shoes off and sit at a lowered table. It was pretty cool. They had cushioned seats without legs that you just pull up to the table and then underneath the table the floor sunk down a step for your legs to hang down. Seemed great for larger parties. Drinks: Who says you shouldn't mix beer and liquor? Oh the sake bombs were flowing all night long. They had a pretty decent drink deal for bigger groups (or a small group of alcoholics) that included 3 pitchers of Kirin and two 750 ml bottles of sake for a hundred bucks. Food: So the first thought that came to mind when I saw their menu was that it wasn't all you can eat and I would probably spend a ton and still leave here hungry. While it's definitely more expensive than a more traditional Korean BBQ place, it wasn't too far off from what you'd expect in river north and surprisingly our group of big eaters left feeling pretty stuffed.It was a bad idea allowing the guys with the biggest appetites to order for the table. The menu suggested you order 1-2 appetizers, 2-3 meats, and 1-2 side dishes per person, so I rounded up in every category and estimated that we would need 7 dishes per person. Based on that, we didn't think it was a big deal ordering 45 items for our table of 6 haha. Garlic rice - Definitely has enough flavor to stand on its own. I probably consumed a whole bulb of garlic with all the rice I ate.  Miso chili wings - Typical sweet/spicy Asian spinBacon chips - Deep fried pieces of bacon that you garnish with rock salt. What kind of evil genius thinks of this? So deliciousFried dumplings - A little bit crispier than normal pan fried gyoza, but the filling is pretty similar. Wasabi crunchy shrimp - Tempura style battered shrimp with a creamy wasabi sauce drizzled on top. Garlic noodles- Super thick noodles that weren't too saucy. Reminded me of Filipino pancit canton. Spicy kalbi ramen - I'm a huge ramen fan but I just wasn't really feelin this. I'm not too big on beef based broths and the flavor just seemed a little off to me. Noodles were meh.Grilled meats - It's tough to describe the differences between each of meats, so let's just say everything was DAMN delicious. Seriously how can you not love marinated meats freshly grilled right in front of you. The best was when a nice char started to form on the outside. We pretty much ordered a little bit of everything. Harami skirt steak - Unique miso marinade. Cooks pretty fastKalbi short rib - The quintessential kBBQ meat. You can never go wrong.Chicken/shrimp/salmon - Nothing too unique about these. Still delicious though.Pork belly - These took a little longer to cook, but nothing beats the flavor of charred pork fat.Toro beef - It's described as beef bacon, so you gotta get itRib eye/filet mignon - Thicker cuts of meat. Came out super juicyOverall, I would say dinner was pretty fantastic, and I would definitely come back despite the whole reservation fiasco. Maybe it's the sake bombs talking but everything was perfect. Food was delicious, drinks were potent, the atmosphere was lively, the 3rd floor seating was unique, and just the whole experience of grilling your own meats at the table was a great way to enjoy dinner with a big group.

57.description: Delicious food! If you go during happy hour, much cheaper and less waiting!

20.description: Not your average dining experience. I went with my cousin & we had a great time! It's like a do it yourself Fogo de Chao. It was so cold outside in Chicago so once we sat down we literally started warming our hands over the grill, which was perfect.We ordered the Samurai option for two with the s'mores dessert. Everything was delicious. It was my first time trying the miso soup & the tuna appetizer plus I never had a s'more till this night. Overall highly recommend!

36.description: This place was very fun. Good for groups. Service was very helpful (we had something wrong with our little burner, which they fixed right away!). Would recommend to a friend.

14.description: What does Gyu-Kaku mean? I dunno, but for me,  it means good eats, cool ambience and great service! The staff is very helpful when it comes to cooking times, and will assist as needed. There's a prepared-food menu for those that aren't cool enough to bbq there own dinner (weak!)Great for groups, or date night.Try the third for seating area, for an authentic , shoes-off experience.

58.description: Delicious, many healthy options, excellent fast service, cute atmosphere, will dine here again, even though I have a short stay in town.

56.description: If you can tell food is made with love than this place is the opposite. The food isn't disgusting, but it was just bland, boring, and not fresh. The service was nice though.

29.description: The best corned beef hash I have had in Chicago. Perfectly cooked eggs, pleasant wait person, clean, fast service and good coffee; my new go to place for breakfast.

42.description: Food was good (Omelette and breakfast burrito). Service was good. Right across the street from our hotel. Done.

23.description: Loved this place. Was in town for a week. Went every day. Service a little laid back but it's morning - who has time to rush?

47.description: The food was great! I recommend the turkey Benedict, there was hardly any wait on a Saturday morning so that is really nice. Our waitress was very attentive, and I love the self serve coffee and water right on the table. Only bad thing. It was a little loud because we sat too close to the dish station. Other than that it was a great breakfast

8.description: I like this spot because it's casual and reminds me a bit of back home in KY. It's not country or anything - it's just simple in decor and good food. A bit more spacious than many breakfast options. Good location with being near Mag mile but towards the lake where it's a tad quieter. It was a perfect spot to eat during my stay at the Double Tree hotel right next door. Really appreciate the whole wheat walnut pancake with sugar free syrup and the healthy broccoli spinach omelet options. The coffee was delicious. I ate a whole pot by myself! Also loved how the water picture with lemon in it sat on the table upon being seated! Only reason they don't get five stars is because the food wasn't hot which was a disappointment for how much I was looking forward to splurging on a pancake!

31.description: Props for doing the poached egg right!. Wanted to try grits for my first time here too, though was told it's a bit soupy. Great casual breakfast spot-- would travel out of my way for their poached eggs!

34.description: Other than my scrambled egg coming to the table like a fried egg, everything was well. The blueberry pancakes were large and tasty, definitely a "shareable" portion. The bacon was tasty and crispy and not soggy-the eat bacon should be :-) The server was very friendly, I was seated promptly.

16.description: Finally found a good breakfast/brunch place near Streeterville, that won't break the budget. West Egg feels like a small-town diner, imported into a big-city location. And when it's early in the morning, that's just what the doctor ordered. When you enter the building, you might be a little concerned depending on what door you walk through. They're going through construction right now so one of the entrances seems like it's a for-sale property, still undergoing renovations(much like the rest of Chicago). Once you make it inside though you'll be pleasantly surprised to see quaint tables, friendly waitresses, and an unmistakable smell of eggs, pancakes and everything else breakfast.The menu is fairly normal size for a diner, featuring a wide variety of different pancakes, waffles, omelets, and other breakfast specials(many with, but also many without, egg). I got the Biscuits and Sausage Gravy, which came with home-fried potatoes, a sausage link, and two eggs cooked to my specifications. My friends got two omelets, and a California crepe(sort of like a very thin rolled omelet, but filled with avocado and other vegetables and topped with alfalfa sprouts). The food itself was all good, though the omelets seemed a little more dense and less fluffy than I usually prefer. The biscuits were flavorful, though they could have been fluffier. Quite enjoyed the sausage gravy, wish they could have spooned a little more of it on. Eggs were cooked perfectly and the homefries were crispy as well. Granted, I was not wowed by West Egg, but I would come back here again. Solid food, Solid portions, Solid price; Especially in the streeterville area it's good to see a local breakfast spot that I'd be proud to be a regular at.

13.description: Tried another brunch place but wouldn't deal with the 2 hour wait.  I found this little gem instead.   Great service.  A pitcher of water waiting for you at the table.  Very little wait time despite the big crowd.   I had the Haileys English Walnut pancakes..amazing.   They brought over warmed honey and some blueberries for a topping. Two pancakes was sufficient.   I also tried the Feta Frittata which is very good.   I was impressed with the healthy breakfast options.  I can't wait to visit again.

11.description: If you haven't tried West Egg Cafe you are definitely missing out! The food is great. They have SO many choices! Every time I come here I try something different and they never fail to satisfy me. The kitchen manager Victor is always very nice to us. My favorite breakfast cafe

39.description: Great restaurant! Reasonable prices, great service with attentive waitstaff, healthy options available...

37.description: Quick turnover of tables. Went 9 am day before the marathon. Lots of people, but short wait. Very professional. Tables set before you sit down. Had the California omelet topped with alfalfa sprouts. Fresh broccoli, mushrooms and avocado.  Side cup of a celery seed sweet vinaigrette. Side of fruit or potatoes. Delicious!

0.description: Great find .Walking I found this gem and was able to get in about 9am. After I left, there was a 1-1/2 hr wait. The menu us a wide range ( for folks like me that don't eat bacon, eggs, biscuits, Gravy etc. , but it also looked great.Service was awesome. I will be back many times. Could use more non pork meat items.

38.description: We were craving a breakfast and couldn't get up at the usual time for breakfast with time zone change. This place is local, open until 3 and was AWESOME. The menu was really great with everything you could ask for and more and the staff was friendly. We got our own coffee pot and water jug and they checked on us regularly.  Would recommend if your in Chicago. Must try!

51.description: I cringe at the thought of tipping at this place.  They mess up your order and only come an ask you if you need anything when you don't.  It's the worst thing when you have to get up to find your server and let them know that you're ready to check out.  The only reason I tip is just so that the stereotype doesn't further extend, but we all know it will never change anyhow.The food is average and is only played up by it's hipster meets yuppie atmosphere.  I now know why I hadn't been to the place for a year.

27.description: Wonderful breakfast! Breakfast burrito with chicken was huge and serviced with potatoes and fruit. My husband had the country fried steak. Hands down the best country fried steak ever! Great service

32.description: Really enjoyed our breakfast. The place was very busy on the weekend, but they got us in quickly and the food was out fast. Our server Jonathan was very attentive. Great food. Great service.

54.description: Fast, Friendly, personal service! Great staff. Loved the breakfast. Pancakes are wonderful! Prices are reasonable. Would definitely recommend to my friends!

48.description: The West Egg Cafe is an okay place to get breakfast, but it isn't going to be an outstanding experience and the food won't blow you away. If you're looking for some basic pancakes, eggs, breakfast potatoes at a sub-$10 cost, it works well. The service here was lacking. It took 10 minutes for someone to come by to take our order. When we wanted the check, it was 15 minutes of waiting for our waiter to come by.

44.description: Came here on a rainy Saturday for brunch. The wait is pretty good for brunch in Streeterville. Got a table for three in 20 minutes. The menu is typical of a brunch place - omelettes, skillets, pancakes. Didn't see anything on the menu that really stood out to me. I got a ham and mushroom skillet, which was good. It came with a small cup of fruit and an english muffin.  Ambience is a small diner feel. Unpretentious though a little loud. The staff is friendly. I thought the food was a bit generic, but it's a great place for a casual brunch with plenty of choices.

24.description: A bright little breakfast place in downtown . It's a fun place to eat and people watch . The only downside when we went was the service was a little slow . The food was great !!! The special skillet is :  Potatoes , cheese , green chiles , guacamole and eggs , a great combination ! the green chiles weren't spicy but still good .

7.description: A bright little breakfast place in downtown . It's a fun place to eat and people watch . The only downside when we went was the service was a little slow . The food was great !!! The special skillet is :  Potatoes , cheese , green chiles , guacamole and eggs , a great combination ! the green chiles weren't spicy but still good .

49.description: Rainy Chicago morning. But West Egg warm and ready for Saturday morning!  Great food and lovely servers. Eggs, steak, and bacon, of course!

40.description: Grab a cup of that diner coffee and get a skillet - top it off with bacon, andouille sausage, chorizo and mushrooms - and you won't regret it! I call it the "Meat Your Maker" skillet.

53.description: Finally found a good breakfast/brunch place near Streeterville, that won't break the budget. West Egg feels like a small-town diner, imported into a big-city location. And when it's early in the morning, that's just what the doctor ordered. When you enter the building, you might be a little concerned depending on what door you walk through. They're going through construction right now so one of the entrances seems like it's a for-sale property, still undergoing renovations(much like the rest of Chicago). Once you make it inside though you'll be pleasantly surprised to see quaint tables, friendly waitresses, and an unmistakable smell of eggs, pancakes and everything else breakfast.The menu is fairly normal size for a diner, featuring a wide variety of different pancakes, waffles, omelets, and other breakfast specials(many with, but also many without, egg). I got the Biscuits and Sausage Gravy, which came with home-fried potatoes, a sausage link, and two eggs cooked to my specifications. My friends got two omelets, and a California crepe(sort of like a very thin rolled omelet, but filled with avocado and other vegetables and topped with alfalfa sprouts). The food itself was all good, though the omelets seemed a little more dense and less fluffy than I usually prefer. The biscuits were flavorful, though they could have been fluffier. Quite enjoyed the sausage gravy, wish they could have spooned a little more of it on. Eggs were cooked perfectly and the homefries were crispy as well. Granted, I was not wowed by West Egg, but I would come back here again. Solid food, Solid portions, Solid price; Especially in the streeterville area it's good to see a local breakfast spot that I'd be proud to be a regular at.

30.description: Came here for lunch because it was close to church. Food was just okay. Standard breakfast fare. We all got omelettes. If you're in a bind, it's not the worst you could do, but there are definitely better lunch venues in downtown Chicago.

46.description: Since I've been coming here for at least 5 years I thought that I already had given this gem a review already. This is a strong 4. Some days and visits it's a 5. Splendid location and great staff. Could be a little crowded if you're late. The food is always a 5.My recommendations:Albuquerque Turkey BenedictBandito Omelette The Grabowski, with smoked polish sausage.

1.description: Came here with my mom when we were staying in downtown Chicago. Pretty standard breakfast. Quick service. We were seated right away, our food came out relatively fast. Staff wasn't too interested in providing detailed answers to our questions but that's okay.I thought my breakfast was standard but totally adequate. My mom had something off the "Healthy" menu. The bran muffin was awesome but I doubt it was actually healthy. Tasted too sweet and amazing to be low sugar or anything like that. I mean, I'm sure there was some bran in it, but it tasted like something off the "beware" list on a dieting magazine for things that seem healthy but actually are not. I had an egg white omelette and ate the whole thing. It was good. Potatoes were nothing to write home about but again totally fine.Coffee was also fine and I liked that they serve it with the pot because my version of a cup of coffee is actually a pot of coffee.I'll come back if I'm in the area but wouldn't go out of my way....probably more interesting places to eat in the city.

55.description: Food is delicious. I had the spinach and mushroom crepe and yogurt with granola. The wait was not too bad - it moved fairly well. My only complaints are that their coffee - superior brand - is NOT good. I had the cappuccino and my friend had a regular coffee. Both left a lot to be desired. And the portions are huge. I felt really bad wasting half my meal, but when I order a crepe I don't expect THREE. But the food is delicious and I would definitely go back. If they change their coffee I would give them 5 stars

9.description: We had a wonderful experience here. We were looking for an alternative to crappy overpriced hotel buffet. Two giant breakfasts for $20 an awesome waiter and a cute little place a short walk from the magnificent mile.

26.description: Good food, good service, good price. Nothing special, but a good choice for an easy breakfast

25.description: Came on Saturday, food wasn't bad, we had the turkey eggs benedict. But the line was ridiculous! If I lived in Chicago I would eat breakfast at home. These lines aren't worth it. Seated at the counter in a spot were the Fair banks entrance door was constantly being opened and the cold and wind blew all over us. The service was spotty with condiments missing and having to reach for stuff over other diners. Not worth it! Lock the door and make every body enter in one spot to prevent the draft. Restrooms at the end of a weird under construction/industrial stairwell. Has to be better places.

12.description: I had an AWESOME breakfast at the bar one sunny Saturday morning. I had the avocado/huevos rancheros meal which was delightful.Food is definitely a 5. The speed and approach to the service was a strong 4. So, somewhere between a 4-5 lies this place.

59.description: Food and service here continues to exceed expectations.  Used to work across street and left 9 years ago.  Return whenever I can.  The Bleu Bayou continues to be awesome.  Management gets it...food served within 5 minutes of seating (was solo and sat at counter).  Couple blocks east of Mich Ave craziness but worth the trip!

21.description: The food itself was mediocre. There was quite a crowd when we got in. The server was quite friendly. I got the steak and eggs. I didn't hate it, but I also didn't like it. My friend got the Michalangelo on recommendation and she just didn't like it. We probably won't go back there if we come to Chicago, nor would we recommend it

17.description: It's a breakfast cafe, right? This one strikes that perfect balance between Chicago-One-Word-Trendy-Hour-Wait-Overpriced place and GreasyIsGood-ButDirty-BadCoffee-Ugly place. Bacado omelette wasn't big--sorta flat--but was tasty and generous portions for the plate. The 6-table sidewalk cafe was really pleasant, my server was kind and on point and went out her way to jump to help people with things.Remove a star because I was trying to do a working lunch, and the wifi wasn't functional. The owner apparently knew about the problem but hasn't fixed it. I connected to a nearby pub wifi instead, which probably is not a fan of West Egg customers poaching.

10.description: Come here for super quick service, especially during lunch hours(on weekdays). The grilled chicken sandwich with bacon and avocado is THE BEST and comes with tasty hashbrowns. This contributed greatly to the 4th star. The roasted chicken option is a good deal as well, although it won't be the best you've ever had. The breakfast items are pretty standard taste-wise(is that a word?), and the pancakes are huge. Definitely will visit over and over again, especially when starving.

5.description: Gord and I had breakfast this morning at the West Egg Cafe.  Gord ordered The Grabowski.  He said it was good and he'd get it again.I got Pork Chops and Eggs.  It was good and I'd get it again.Both were big portions!  There was a lot of food!Jennifer was our server.  She was friendly and took good care of us.We'd go back.

3.description: Egggcelent!! Super hardy and delicious. Best of all, all the people who work there are super friendly and accommodating. We wanted substitutions done to our food and they were completely fine with that and didn't charge us more. It was great.

35.description: So my server was awesome bald dude with a leg tattoo. I forgot to get his name however he was absolutely great and in no way did his services reflect my review . In fact i applud you for working for people who clearly don't give a damn. My fiance and I ordered the turkey eggs bendidict  and  the corned beef and hash. The eggs benedict looked and tasted amazing Hands down the best part of our experience In Your Establishment a unique taste for sure. If I ever come back I know what I would get.It's never a good sign when someone needs to start a new paragraph to talk about the negatives. Here is how it all went south. It took literally 5 min to get our food after we ordered. We were freaked out how fast it came out  obviously did not cook it fresh with time and care.  The corned beef and hash had clearly come from a can. It was an embarrassment to even have been served that slop in your establishment. All the pictures on yelp in no way resembled the cat food I was served today.  It was runnny (not the eggs)and there weren't no actual pieces of corned beef in my C.B.H . Why even have it on the menu if you know it's awful.

19.description: By far one of the best places to get a quick bite to eat that is just off of the mile. The entrance is marked by a small door and a big sign, but as soon as you walk in, it opens to a rather large, bustling facility. What makes this place great is that the waiters/waitresses are speedy all in the right ways . My party and I came in, and were immediately given a pitcher of water and coffee. Within 25 minutes our food was ready, and was DELICIOUS. There really isn't anything bad about this place, I will definitely come back here. Prices were about on the high side of average for breakfast, but trust me, West Egg is almost certainly worth it.

28.description: Great food. I had the club sandwich and it was outstanding. Frenchtoast ok but not fabulous. Staff very atentive.

45.description: I was in town this past weekend and on my last morning in Chicago, decided to have breakfast at West Egg Cafe which was just down the street from my hotel where I was staying. Pretty basic looking cafe but it was clean and there were lots of people there enjoying their meals. I had the Denver scramble which was quite delicious. Nothing too heavy or nor was the proportions huge which was something I wasn't looking for in a breakfast. If you are looking for a place that serves hashbrowns this isn't it. I didn't mind though, I wasn't looking to be in a food coma. Coffee was good too. I could have lived without the crack from the server when I tried to pour the water and some of it ended up on the table and lap. Otherwise it was a nice quick breakfast to get me on my way of some more sight seeing in the city.

33.description: Absolutely love coming to the West egg Café. every time we visit the city this is a must stop for breakfast. Had the eggs Benedict...it's a good classic breakfast to have... Ham was a little on the tough side, which is the only reason that this review is getting four stars instead of five. it's not that it didn't taste good that it was tough to cut through and really hard enjoy the eggs Benedict (didn't finish it) when the ham isn't tender. However all great things to say from the coffee... Which I happen to be very picky about... To a new favorite of ours, the Bacado Omlette!!! If you love avocados and bacon... This is for you! Eggs were delicious and fluffy in the omelette, and we loved loved the potatoes. I ordered a side of salsa which was really great for dipping the potatoes...looked tomatoe-y but had nice flavor.We would be remiss if we didn't tell you that our server and he was delightful. We love that even though it was a busy Saturday morning she took the time to chat with my daughter and I just briefly... And even shared a little life-advice which made it seem like we were visiting an old friend.

43.description: I had an AWESOME breakfast at the bar one sunny Saturday morning. I had the avocado/huevos rancheros meal which was delightful.Food is definitely a 5. The speed and approach to the service was a strong 4. So, somewhere between a 4-5 lies this place.

2.description: In search of a late breakfast that would see us through a plane ride home without paying airport food prices, we found West Egg, and West Egg delivered.The tiny storefront is deceiving; the main dining area goes way back from the street. It was pretty full when we arrived, but a host led us through a side door, through a hallway under construction, and into an even larger space. In contrast to the warm wood of the main dining room, this one is all white, as if it's complete enough to use, but they haven't had time to decorate. They certainly needed the extra space on this morning.I can't think of very many things that'll stick to your ribs more than corned beef hash. West Egg sent out a generous portion, simple but very good, rich but not greasy. It came with some fluffy scrambled eggs and an English muffin, which I could only eat about half of, and a small cup of fruit that was riper and tastier than usual.Our food came out quickly for as busy as they were, and our server was nice. They leave a pitcher of ice water and coffee on your table, which is convenient although it made our table a little crowded. Prices make for an affordable big meal downtown.

18.description: This place is much better than yolk! I ordered mushroom eggcerlence! My friend ordered a bacon omelet. The egg tastes awesome and the potatoes are cooked right to how they should be! Will back again!!

41.description: ICame here just because it was close to hotel. What a treat. Clean, friendly, great coffee and an excellent breakfast, I had the blue bayou and it came with potatoes and an English muffin. Nice introduction to Chicago

52.description: Delicious breakfast  and great service too.  Hearty  portions and they give you your own coffee carafe.  It's only a short walk from magnificent mile hotels.   100 times better than hotel breakfast

50.description: The price was adequate for what we got, which was pleasantly surprising. We got straight in for brunch on a Friday morning, no wait. Really liked the breakfast potatoes, but nothing was really anything to write home about.

4.description: Delicious hash and eggs. Ok pancakes. Great to find a diner in the the city near our hotel

6.description: Four stars for extremely quick food service and large portions at a cheap price.This is without a doubt a quick stop in place. I would say it is very similar in quality and offerings to IHOP, but it's conveniently located and they know how to feed people quickly! Definitely recommend for any tourists needing a change from hotel breakfast or anyone with a group of picky eaters.

22.description: Fast, friendly, and always in/out. I love the Denver scramble, biscuits and gravy, and must try the chicken fried steak. Yum

15.description: Since I've been coming here for at least 5 years I thought that I already had given this gem a review already. This is a strong 4. Some days and visits it's a 5. Splendid location and great staff. Could be a little crowded if you're late. The food is always a 5.My recommendations:Albuquerque Turkey BenedictBandito Omelette The Grabowski, with smoked polish sausage.

57.description: Great place for breakfast in Chicago. The food is really good and the staff is very friendly. My lox scramble was very good.  This is the only place I have breakfast when in town.

20.description: Great find .Walking I found this gem and was able to get in about 9am. After I left, there was a 1-1/2 hr wait. The menu us a wide range ( for folks like me that don't eat bacon, eggs, biscuits, Gravy etc. , but it also looked great.Service was awesome. I will be back many times. Could use more non pork meat items.

36.description: Great brunch spot! Loved the Best Western Omelette.

14.description: We went on a Tuesday morning in February and it was not crowded. We were seated immediately, and it felt like our food arrived almost instantly after we ordered. The Bleu Bayou scramble was excellent, and my daughters enjoyed their strawberry waffles. I imagine this place gets really crowded on summer weekends. Friendly service, casual vibe. A great weekday breakfast experience.

29.description: Great sandwich place now sorely missed.Used to come here every Saturday late morning for the lazy man's guide to breakfast/lunch.Never disappointed. Quick, simple and tasty.Usually got the "A Wreck" or the Italian to satisfy the transition from slumber to semi-awake....

42.description: Five stars because it's a great value!I had one of their "Big" roast beef sandwiches, and it was delicious. But I am most impressed by their salads. I hate when places sell $7+ salads that are jut 90% plain lettuce and croutons. Potbelly's understands this. I had the Italian salad here, and it was chock full of substantial toppings like artichoke hearts, roasted red peppers, chickpeas, cucumbers, grape tomatoes, salami/Italian meats, and cheese, all over quality romaine lettuce. It had croutons too, but not just any croutons, some really good ones. And the Potbelly vinaigrette dressing is really good too.All this for only $5.60 pre-tax. I'm sold.

23.description: Very efficient, friendly service. I've had the "a wreck" as well their pizza sandwich. The pizza sandwich was ok I guess, but I was really impressed with how awesome the wreck sandwich tasted. Having the cream soda and bottled root beers are a definite plus, but sadly weren't as good as I remembered them from my childhood. Either way, major cool points. They're a little busy during the week days with the work crowd at lunch. But on the weekend I was the only person there during lunch hour when I went and I got my food super fast. Definitely check it out. A little pricier than subway, but definitely worth the money.

47.description: This is one of the few times I disagree with most yelpers.  New to Chicago, I was looking for a sandwich and saw tons of raving review reviews all over the city.  I was quite disappointed.  It's absolutely nothing special - in fact, it's one of the most lackluster sandwich shops I know.

8.description: The food here is pretty much the same as any Potbellys, but the service is usually pretty bad. Somehow I always get stuck standing by the register for a few minutes waiting for someone to ring me out. Again, the food's good, but if it's not too far out of your way, I'd recommend going to the location on Chicago Ave.

31.description: I LOVED these sandwiches!  The hot peppers are the bomb!!  My old favorite hot sandwich used to be Earl of Sandwich, but those take the backseat to these!  They use the perfect amount of toppings, and the option for less bread is awesome.  I got an extra to go.

34.description: Restaurant reviewSandwiches galore in Streeterville. I cannot count how many sandwich shops are in this area. Occasionally I throw "A Wreck" (rukey, slamin, roast beef, ham, swiss cheese) into the mix to complement my sandwich intake. Service is slow even when it is not busy, but the staff is friendly. You can upgrade your sandwich to the Big but it doesn't appear that much bigger imho. You can complement your meal with a milkshake that is hand mixed, but again pretty small in size. Otw nothing spectacularly good or bad about this place earns it a average 3 star reviewPro: online ordering available to speed up the process, variety of sandwiches with different meatsCons: slow service, average size sandwiches/milk shakesHidden gem: no exciting deals here

16.description: Potbelly brings you amazing sandwiches at an amazing price.  For $5.50, you can get a big version of their sandwiches.  I'm a big fan of the roast beef.  Whenever I get in line, I'm tempted to try something else, just to see if I love it as much as the roast beef.  But then I think, "Why would I miss out on the opportunity to have that awesome roast beef again?"  And then I revert to my usual.If you're in a sandwich mood, what's your alternative?  Subway?  Feh.  Quizno's? Forget about it.You'll find Potbelly locations all over Chicago.  They are uniformly excellent.  The perfect lunch location.

13.description: I've been to this location 5+ times and the staff have been rude every time. Each visit there have been at least 4 people behind the counter loudly talking to each other and complaining, with one person working. It's awkward to wait for a sandwich with people loudly goofing in front of you. The sandwiches are fine, but I'll walk to the Michigan Ave. location just to avoid the bad customer service.

11.description: Phil the delivery person is amazing. Always is on time with a great attitude. Knows our staff by name. Great job Phil, keep up the good work!

39.description: (sigh..........) is it me or is my pocket book shrinking?  I used to splurge on cheescake and coffee after dinner, now the little pleasures in life are reduced to 10oz shakes which are just as satisfying and 1/3 the calories.  No kidding, for $3 you can get a real (strawberry) shake made with quality vanilla ice cream and 2% milk topped with 2 mini butter cookies.  doesn't get better than this!  Sandwiches are pretty good too, they increased their offerings, (big, reg, skinny etc) toasted hot and fresh with choice of toppings.

37.description: Potbelly brings you amazing sandwiches at an amazing price.  For $5.50, you can get a big version of their sandwiches.  I'm a big fan of the roast beef.  Whenever I get in line, I'm tempted to try something else, just to see if I love it as much as the roast beef.  But then I think, "Why would I miss out on the opportunity to have that awesome roast beef again?"  And then I revert to my usual.If you're in a sandwich mood, what's your alternative?  Subway?  Feh.  Quizno's? Forget about it.You'll find Potbelly locations all over Chicago.  They are uniformly excellent.  The perfect lunch location.

0.description: The experience I just had at this Potbelly's was so refreshing I can't wait to write about it. It's a quiet Saturday morning and the sandwich shop is pleasantly calm. I order right away and the employees are smiling and polite, like always. Even during weekday lunch time, when there's a line of hungry people and it's so hectic, the employees are efficient and friendly. While these lovely people prepare my lunch a family of tourists come bustling in and struggle to order. The line of workers are beyond patient and maintain those smiles, they must be desensitized to the stupid, obnoxious, and rude. Even when one of the children suddenly remembers she doesn't like tuna and wants roast beef and asks for a new sandwich, they smile. I couldn't detect even a hint of snark when they obliged. Despite oblivious and impolite nonsense the crew had to navigate through, the family got their food and was able to enjoy their meal. This Potbelly's team deserves an award, or at least your respect. I appreciate the food (delicious, duh) but I enjoy the experience because of the staff. Keep it up, guys.

38.description: In Chicago for a conference and stumbled upon this gem near my hotel. It was packed at lunchtime, which is always a good sign. I order a Wreck (turkey, ham, roast beef & salami) sandwich, which turned out to be one of the best sandwiches I've ever had. Washed it down with a banana-boysenberry shake that came with two little cookies on the straw. Was a bit of a wait since it was lunch, but was worth it. I'd go back to Chicago just to go there again, it's that good. The staff was friendly, the atmosphere is nice inside and the prices are very affordable for what you get--the portions are a great value. It's in a great location too--about a 15-20 minute walk to Navy Pier.

51.description: Potbelly's has mastered the art of getting a ton of people through here in a short amount of time.  Because this is right on Northwestern's campus, there's an endless supply of people coming through during lunch time.  It's never taken more than 10 minutes from when I walk in the door until I walk out, however, which basically can't be beat.  These are the only baked sandwiches that I like.They miss one star on the annoying live music, however.  I really don't care for to hear someone ruin songs that I like on an acoustic guitar. =P

27.description: I just came here last week during a weekday lunch rush.The quality of the sandwich is more or less the same, but holy crap--the stress during lunch really gets to the workers and makes them quite nasty.I'd recommend coming here if there isn't a crowd there on their lunch break. It's an absolute mess.

32.description: This franchise location just went to WINNING with the advent of acquiring a fountain machine, which means free refills!  Tit for tat, I guess, but I feel Potbelly's isn't as cheap as it used to be.  Anyways, this locale is pretty cool, with their acoustic troubadores and everything.  It's a nice little getaway for an hour's break from work.

54.description: Preface: I love Potbelly's!  Period. The two stars are for this location only -- specifically,  b/c it's not stroller/wheelchair accessible. Found this out after speedwalking here, hungry for lunch, after a dentist appt. After navigating the entrance (uphill, always tricky w/ a stroller), I was stunned to see another short flight of stairs to the order line.  If I was with someone else, it'd be doable. But I wasn't, so we left disappointed.  I wound up soothing myself with a Potbelly's fix in the burbs, capped by a mocha shake.EDIT 1/25/07: A Yelper who used to work here was nice enough to PM me to let me know that there is, apparently, an elevator on the premises.  I am glad to hear it: I'll head here when I'm next in the neighborhood. But I do think they should have more prominent signage re: the elevator.

48.description: I am surprised by some of the poor reviews of this location.  I worked for a little over a year about a block away.  This place became one of my regular lunch spots.  The one thing that always amazed me was how efficient and polite the workers were here.  Even if they have a huge line they move it quick and they almost always get your sandwich right.  The workers at the checkout were always cheery instead of frantic and rushed.  I loved coming here for that reason.  The food is the same that you will get at any other Potbelly's.

44.description: After spending $7+ on mediocre to bad sandwiches all summer in the suburbs of California, I am really excited about Potbelly's.  This is the best $4 sandwich I've ever had.  It reminds me of Sandwich World in Newport Beach, CA--but better and only 2/3 the price!It's not the greatest or most creative sandwich, but it's:-neatly made and doesn't fall apart when you try to eat it;-tastes good--I really like the hot peppers here;-and warm--the bread is toasted!I got "A Wreck" (salami, ham, turkey, roast beef, swiss) and a chocolate chip oatmeal cookie.  The cookies are also a lot better than in most bakery cafes in California, but they're not "fly out to chicago to eat a cookie and visit me while you're here" good.  I'd say they're worth the calories and well-priced at 99 cents, though.My total came out to under $6 AFTER tax.  And the nice lady at the register gave me an extra cookie, which made me feel more welcome on my first visit to Potbelly's.  Maybe she felt bad for me because my purse clashed with my shirt.  Who knows.  I thought it was nice of her.  In fact, everyone there seemed really nice.  I'll definitely be back.

24.description: PBs is good for when you just need to get in and out after work. The Sands are no better than any other sand-shop to me.

7.description: Don't expect them to be ready to serve customers in the first 15 minutes after opening. That's apparently the time when they're setting up and arguing among themselves. Not impressed.

49.description: It's a decent spot to go for lunch or if your in a rush. Much better then McDonalds thats for sure, but, it is just a hot sandwich. Stay away from the tuna /chicken salad I have known a few people who have gotten food poising at other locations.

40.description: I don't know if it's just this particular Potbelly location, or if all the stores are doing it...but they now make their salads with wilty iceberg lettuce instead of romaine. This used to be my go-to place for lunchtime salads. A big salad of roasted red peppers, cucumbers, chickpeas and fresh ROMAINE lettuce, all for about 6 bucks was once a good deal...but the switch to iceberg does make a difference. This salad is now overpriced and hardly even worth eating.

53.description: Picked up a meatball sandwich here on a windy Chicago day (redundant, I know).  While tasty, nothing in there really stood out.  The meat and marinara were so-so.  They didn't really do anything wrong per-say, but there was nothing to write home about.  I suppose it could have become a regular sandwich place for me, but Eppy's Deli (yelp.com/biz/dNiqAVt4AlT…) across the street is my choice.Updated August 2007: Yup, still just as crappy as I remember it.

30.description: we were looking for something quick, and had seen this chain around chicago all week.  so glad we stopped in.  the menu seemed a little complicated, but there are steps that walk you right through it, plus the friendly staff help make the experience less threatening.  I ordered the "Wreck" which consisted of salami, roast beef, turkey, and ham.  since it was my firstt time, i ordered it with everything on it.  so glad i did.  the sandwich was amazing!!  would definitely go back. wish we had Potbelly in California!

46.description: I love Potbelly's and wish they had one here in CA.  A friend kept raving about their sandwiches, and he was right - they are good!  All sandwiches cost $4.19 and come on toasted wheat or white, which is key.  They can also add a bunch of stuff - I tried the Chicken Salad sandwich (it was dry, but I had it the next day so I'm not sure if this was the reason or not), the Italian (my favorite), and the Wreck.  I also had a chocolate malt, which was extremely thick and rich.   I'm not a huge fan of their sugar cookies but prefer and love their oatmeal chocolate chips cookies instead.  I brought a few back w/ me from my trip.  FYI - they normally cost $.99 but for some reason cost $1.09 at the MDW airport.

1.description: I am simply not a fan of Potbelly's menu, however, I am in love with their cookies. I really like this location because it is in a fairly low traffic area. Each time I have visited the shop, I rarely ever have to wait. I cannot speak much on anything else other than the freshness of the cookies because that Is all I ever order from here. They are in fact always fresh and chewy. The sugar cookies are to die for. The help here is pretty basic. They get the job done. Not very personable but not rude. They just exist. I think this is a great place to get work done.

55.description: Potbelly's is to die for!  The sandwichs are great...nice and toasty with a consistancy I can't believe.  They are cheap too!!!  This location gets really busy around lunch time with Northwestern students, hospital employees, people working in the area, and shoppers coming off of Michigan Ave.  There is a nice outdoor seating place here too.  Also, their smoothies/malts are AMAZING...you gotta try one!

9.description: Good sandwiches, reasonably priced.Didn't feel like going out to eat, so went to pick up some dinner from the Potbelly location less than a block away from the hotel.  Ordered a turkey breast sandwich, an Italian sandwich, and a Farmhouse salad.  The person taking my order must have been in training or something, since the process seemed to take forever, and then the person making my food didn't know about the salad.  In spite of this, we enjoyed our meal from Potbelly.Sandwiches were tasty, although I'd leave off the hot peppers unless you like really spicy sandwiches.  Well, maybe just ask them to use half as much and you'll be okay.  The salad had a surprising amount of goodies, not just a iceberg-dominated affair.  Altogether very good.

26.description: you're two blocks from the largest handicap rehabilitation center in chicago - mind you in the middle of chicago's hospital district - and your store has a wheelchair lift that is completely surrounded by tables and chairs. hey, we all like profits. but show some f@$#ing respect.not cool man. not cool.

25.description: Can't lie, usually don't do chains but this one is a hit!!

12.description: Very busy PotBelly's, but they always somehow make it through.  The staff are nice.  I was there this week and it seemed a big unorganized, but that is not normal so I will let it slide.

21.description: Wow! This is the best sandwich shop that I've ever been in. Honestly you have to come here. The food is great and so is the service.

17.description: They may make great sandwiched while you watch them but their delivery sandwiches are BAD!!   I ordered the chicken salad with extra meat and the chicken salad did not even cover the bread!  I tried again with the Mediterranean chicken and I got 3 small pieces of chicken.  I called and the manager said they would send me a coupon...never came.

10.description: What a great sandwich!!  The bread is delicious and the meat and toppings are fresh.  I had fantastic service and they were so friendly and excited to serve me, especially when they found out I was from Mississippi.  A great place for a quick, delicious meal and for a great price!

5.description: A lot of these reviews seem to center on the slow service but I didn't have a problem. When I walked in there are approximately 15 people in line but they did have a guy going up and down the line taking your order and the sandwich was ready for me when I got up to the counter. So I have no complaints about the service because they are making an effort and the sandwich is comparable to the other locations.

3.description: Horrible service, they should be ashamed at how slow they are. After waiting ten minutes to make my salad, then ten more to ring me up, I left. They workers are incredibly rude and ignorant. The manager should be embarrassed.

35.description: Its a Potbellys, take it or leave it.  Gotta give 5 stars though for the friendly and prodigiously productive staff.

19.description: PBs is good for when you just need to get in and out after work. The Sands are no better than any other sand-shop to me.

28.description: What's there to say that hasn't been said already. Potbelly is a pretty good sandwich spot. It's nothing crazy. The meat used is probably really processed and I tend to stay away but it taste pretty good. I'm partial to the wreck but trying to stick to the TKY for calories. The only sandwhich I don't like is the tuna (I hate celery) and I didn't think the meatball was that tasty. Granted, I haven't tried the meatball in years.  I am curious about this new sicilian but that could kill me. I'm a big fan of the chili and of the shakes and smoothies. I appreciate the little cookies on the straw. The cookies and brownies are good and I love IBC root beer as a selection. I do, however, think the salads are terrible. You can just taste the fact that the lettuce comes in a bag. For the price, fresh produce would be appreciated.For that reason I give Potbelly 3.5 stars but round down for the salads. Most Potbellys are the same and I've only had an issue at one place where the workers are just slow.  I won't review each Potbelly place so this is my review for all.Potbelly is close to work so I'll stop in once in a while when I didn't bring lunch and Chipotle or a food truck is not an option.

45.description: I hate that so many of my reviews are 4 stars...but I can't give this place 5 stars...it's not that good.With that said though, I do really enjoy Potbellys.  I love the giardinaire that is put on the sandwiches.  I make them put extra because it is so good when it's spicy!!  I'm not a big fan of lunch meat in general, so I normally get the pizza or cheese sandwich...and I've been meaning to try the pb&j (sans the peppers of course).  I love how they toast them and I actually like the bread a lot.Oh and their breakfast sandwiches are delicious.  I always get one before my morning flights out of midway...yummy!

33.description: I love Potbelly's and for some reason I don't get the opportunity to go there very often.  I went in on Saturday for lunch and service was quick and efficient.  I got a turkey with swiss on white.  I'm kind of picky and everything I requested was on there and nothing I didn't request.  I like the contrast between the warm bread and the cool lettuce.  Very yummy when you're in the  mood for a simple sandwich.

43.description: Okay, so before I come off as a major biotch I would like to say I am all about people having fun especially at work but there is a time and place for everything. So here goes my lovely potbelly story. One rainy night I was too lazy to cook so I walked my lazy ass down the street to the nearest potbelly. I walk in there are about a total of 3 people in line and prolly 5 workers, one of which is singing at the top of her lungs singing some laaame song. What is this, Coldstone? Please stop signing. SO I walk up to order my sandwich--it takes the sandwich making guy like legit 7 minutes to slap some turkey on my wheat bread and sent it through the oven, then I have to wait another 8 mintes before the next guy is ready to put the rest of the jazz of my sandwich all the while I'm thinking to myself, " what the shit is taking so long!?!" Come on people, finish your conversation after I leave with my sammich. I have places to be and Gossip Girl to watch! And P.S. their bread totally hurts the top of my mouth. The end.

2.description: Potbellys! I can never call it Potbelly, that just sounds weird.Anyway, this location is fantastic for the medical district! I love coming to lunch here. Contrary to other potbellys I have been to, this one does not have an acoustic guitar player during the weekday lunch. However, there is an ample amount of space and the service is really fast. The sandwiches are always made to perfection and everyone is super friendly!

18.description: Very efficient, friendly service. I've had the "a wreck" as well their pizza sandwich. The pizza sandwich was ok I guess, but I was really impressed with how awesome the wreck sandwich tasted. Having the cream soda and bottled root beers are a definite plus, but sadly weren't as good as I remembered them from my childhood. Either way, major cool points. They're a little busy during the week days with the work crowd at lunch. But on the weekend I was the only person there during lunch hour when I went and I got my food super fast. Definitely check it out. A little pricier than subway, but definitely worth the money.

41.description: This place it probably the best sub sandwich shop in the city. This location is also probably a gold mine. Sometimes, I cannot get over the fact that I'm waiting in line for something I could have made at home for one quarter of the price and have access to my own bathroom.I sometimes think these places are a form of financial punishment for the absent-minded people who forget to take their lunch from home.But in the end, this place makes a good sandwich and its employees are always courteous and efficient.

52.description: I'm a fan of Potbelly's, not a huge fan, but enough to pick it over Subway and Quizno's. I wasn't impressed by this location though. The Potbelly's I remember from Ann Arbor put a strong emphasis on hiring loud, friendly "sandwich artists" who make your eating experience fun. In fact, a case study done by kids in my business class found that part of Potbelly's model is based off of just that. They want the whole yelling orders down the line, interacting with customers, etc. This location sucked at that. Not friendly, not excited to yell "Oreo Milkshake!" and I got attitude from one of them when I couldn't hear what she was saying. They do still try to have live entertainment though and I enjoyed the guitar guy singing his rendition of Karma Police.

50.description: I was very happy that I decided to venture away from my usual at Fox and Obel for lunch today.  A toasty roast beef sandwich (and of course a giganto pickle) really hit the spot on a cold day like this.  The service was friendly and very efficient here and even though there was a line, it didn't take long for me to be on my way.  If it weren't so cold today I would have gotten one of their deadly ice cream sandwiches made with two of the delicious soft cookies they have.  It's a monster.  This location's layout is a bit of a pain in the butt, but other than that, I'll add this to my lunch lineup.

4.description: "Dad, let's just go Subway. "I wasn't going to let that happen while in chi-town. Went a block or so further and found this place. Verrry friendly staff who were helpful in many ways, answering questions, and were patient with us as we took our time and ordered. Had a wreck, an Italian, smoked turkey, 2 others and just a cup of chicken salad. Everything was great!  Loved the bread, toasted the sandwiches, and even though the fixings were limited, they were spot on.  Cute little table in a 2 tiered room with windows overlooking the street was comfortable and kept clean.While we were leaving..."Dad, thanks for not taking us to Subway!"Sooooo good. Yum.

6.description: I'm not so sure if this is the one I'm obsessed with, but I love it! As well as all the other Potbelly's I have been to. Every time I go here (not that often, mind you) I am greeted with the fresh aroma of sandwiches! Totally awesome! I usually order some cheddar sun chips, the turkey+Swiss cheese sandwich, toasted, with a reasonable amount of mayo, along with a banana shake. Every single bite (and unladylike slurp) is pure heaven. Service is just service. TRY THE BROWNIE COOKIES AND TRY THEM NOW!!!!But not without me.

22.description: Good as always, limited seating at this location however.

15.description: Restaurant reviewSandwiches galore in Streeterville. I cannot count how many sandwich shops are in this area. Occasionally I throw "A Wreck" (rukey, slamin, roast beef, ham, swiss cheese) into the mix to complement my sandwich intake. Service is slow even when it is not busy, but the staff is friendly. You can upgrade your sandwich to the Big but it doesn't appear that much bigger imho. You can complement your meal with a milkshake that is hand mixed, but again pretty small in size. Otw nothing spectacularly good or bad about this place earns it a average 3 star reviewPro: online ordering available to speed up the process, variety of sandwiches with different meatsCons: slow service, average size sandwiches/milk shakesHidden gem: no exciting deals here

20.description: Good sandwiches- you really can't go wrong.  Just had 'The Wreck' and a strawberry shake...and BBQ chips.  All good.Generally plenty of room to eat at the establishment too- sometimes they have live music which is pretty thoughtful.

36.description: I kept seeing locations all over Chicago while I was visiting so I stopped at the one down the street from my hotel for lunch one day. This is a solid sandwich spot if you're looking for something better than Subway or Quiznos. The sandwiches are very tasty and I like that you can order a handmade ice cream sandwich. The only complaint I have is that the bread wrecks the roof of your mouth because they toast the sandwiches. If you have your sandwich with hot peppers, this becomes a double whammy - hot peppers and open wounds do not mix. I suppose you can ask them to not toast your sandwich but the bread didn't look too appealing untoasted - like it was underbaked on purpose so that it finishes when it's toasted.It still beats the other chain sandwich shops, though.

14.description: The sandwiches and service are great, especially for how cheap everything is. It can get a bit busy during the lunch hour, but the line usually goes by in less than 15 minutes even if it is backed up to the door. I would recommend trying the Wreck on their new flatbread - my new favorite go-to when I'm here. I also always get a brownie cookie when they aren't sold out.Oh, and they also have a secret menu of sandwiches that Potbelly employees are trained to make but aren't listed on the in-store menu. You can find the secret menu online through Google if you are interested, Some of them are also pretty tasty!

28.description: This rooftop bar offers a great view of the city.  i recommend getting there early because outdoor seating is limited.  The drinks were amazing and strong, but on the pricey side.  I ordered some food as well and it was wonderful.  The staff was friendly and welcoming.  The bartender came out and checked on us as well to make sure we were having a great experience.  It is worth the visit and I will be back again.

1.description: Great casual place with a really great view. I was staying in the hotel so I decided to come up for a drink. It was around 9pm on a Friday night and the place had plenty of open seats. I would however, not recommend the Old Fashioned. Maybe it's because I'm from Wisconsin and I have high expectations for my Old Fashioneds, but it was really heavy on the simple syrup. And, I'm pretty sure it wasn't muddled. All wrong. I then had the Tennessee Mule, which was better, but not delicious. They used sour when, they really should be using something like lime juice. Neither drink was really worth the $14. I can make far better stuff at home. For way cheaper. I would have given this place 3 stars, but the laid back atmosphere and great view were redeeming in my book. Plus, the service was awesome. Very attentive and kind.

9.description: Impressive! I stayed at this hotel on a whim over the weekend, not really expecting much. It turns out that it is quite the hidden gem. The rooftop bar is really modern and low key, but with a great view, drink, & food selection. We went to the Signature Lounge prior to retiring to our hotel for drinks at this bar and I have to say I enjoyed it a lot more. I had some apple cider, truffle fries, & sliders and I was extremely impressed. The food was delicious, I would come back just to eat. The customer service was also really amazing. I highly recommend this place.

29.description: i was recently a guest at the hotel so I didn't have to put in a lot of effort to get here. The newly reopened lounge on the 29th floor looks fantastic, inside and out. It opens at 5pm daily. I just wanted to hang out on a Sunday night and it was perfect. It's open air, but the walls are high enough to keep most of the wind out. Sunset and nightime views were impressive and like the other reviewer said, the music sets the mood. Some Massive Attack!The downside is that the drinks are pricey, but seems like the norm for places with a view in Chicago (ie $15 a drink). But that also keeps it from getting too crowded I'm sure. Which was the other great thing about it...not crowded at all.I regret not checking it out sooner in my trip

23.description: It was pretty easy getting a couch outside on the rooftop on a Friday at 5:30 PM-- which was a relief, since the last time I tried a rooftop in Gold Coast on a weekend, it was aggravating *cough* DRUMBAR *cough*. The crowd was older than I was expecting though, and it was quieter for a Friday night than I was expecting, even after 7:00 PM. But maybe it gets rowdier later.... we ended leaving for somewhere else with more liveliness.The drinks weren't bad though--- but then again, nothing really amazing. Doesn't make my list of memorable rooftops in Chicago.

5.description: The only bad thing I can say is it's not big...So if you had to stand up for an extended period that wouldn't be the best experience. But that's par for the course when it comes to most rooftops in Chicago. Sure the Wit and I/O are large, but the service you receive at those places depends largely on when you go. Also getting upstairs can be a pain in the rear on the weekend.52eighty has a scotch selection that's awesome; a good food selection (i had the truffle fries with sliders...quite tasty); and the service was good and not pretentious. I would definitely come back.

25.description: There is something to be said about lofty heights and city views while sipping a cocktail.  They create perfect harmony. I feel a tad more confident when sipping a nice bubbly, with legs crossed, and oversized sunglasses donned.  52Eighty is rooftop perfection.  It exudes glam and offers celebrity status (at least the feeling) while sitting on their one of their cushioned outdoor couches.  Manny the bartender is classy.  He is the kind of mixologist that remembers your name and your drink.  To boot, you get a cheek kiss and hospitality if you pay him with a smile for his service.  It does cost real money at 52Eighty.  Smiles are not accepted as payment, but the drinks and people watching make it difficult to wipe one off your face.

12.description: One of the great views of Chicago. Service is quick and polite, it's a very intimate setting, Chicago summers make this a premium location for drinks. Open until midnight on weekdays. Great date spot, enjoy the view and drinks...

21.description: Bartenders are very nice. The drinks are strong and good, but expensive of course $14 each for ours. Pretty easy to get a spot, not too crowded or loud. The crowd is older and more mellow. Nice place to relax with a cocktail and just enjoy the view.

16.description: Really nice rooftop lounge area. Came here with a group of friends for NYE and really enjoyed our experience. Too bad it was way cold to go out on the actual rooftop, though I would love to be back to check it out in the summertime. The lounge inside is edgy, sleek, and modern. Pretty small but makes for a nice, calmer atmosphere. Coordinator that night was really kind and patient with our group. The bar seemed a little overwhelmed (understandably) but selection seemed great. Doesn't have a tv so we were counting down based on the time on someone's phone, which was a little janky, but we had fun.

17.description: Love love love swanky places and this is a hidden rooftop gem.  I wish I would have known about this place before the cold front came in, but I will definitely be back when it gets warmer for the roof top.  However I will be back during the winter the view is spectacular great service the drinks are terrific a bit pricey but made well if you not what I mean, all you need is two drinks and your good to go.

10.description: We came here for drinks in the evening. The outdoor bar can get really hot on a sunny day, so plan to come here in the evening when you can feel the cool breeze, however you will enjoy the breathtaking view. The drinks are moderately strong, and appropriately priced for the location. The service was friendly, and fast. Not that loud so a good place to hang out with friends.

11.description: I was looking for a nice bar to appreciate the skyline, and this one hit the spot.  Great beer on tap, delicious french fries, and a relaxed atmosphere.

26.description: Very close to where we parked on superior. The rooftop lounge is cute. It has a really nice view. Very small and a chill vibe. I didn't have a drink. They were priced the norm for venues such as this. $12-$14 I had the beef sliders and fries. They were a touch could for my liking and I ordered lemonade and it was too tart. I would come for the view and the fact that it's not super crowded like other rooftops.

27.description: You can probably count the number of perfect weather days we get in a Chicago summer on your fingers and toes. Well...with one of those days I totally recommend a visit to this rooftop. It's chic, has great views, comfy furniture, and an outdoor TV. Pair these features with some really tasty upscale bar snacks and you've got yourself a pretty fantastic Sunday evening out if it's not raining. And if it is you can bring the experience inside and sit at the bar which is under shelter. The food menu flaunts unique flavors including some awesome scallops, ceviche, and a foie gras peanut butter and jelly sandwich (yes, you read correct) that'll knock your socks off. The cocktail menu is small, but clever with some interesting spins on their bubbles. It's a bit pricey, but you can chalk it up as being an altitude tax. After all...everything is a little bit better at 29 floors up.

0.description: This place has breathtaking views of the city. It's not crowded either! Was here on a Saturday night from about 9-11. Prices are very reasonable for food and drinks, and the food and bartender are great! We got the crispy risotto balls and scallops. The portions were fair, almost generous actually. It was clear that if was fresh too. Would be back again. Keep it up guys!

20.description: The service, the new bar menu, and the atmosphere is impressive. We couldn't have asked for a better night. The management is exceptional and the drinks are very good.  The bartenders can make anything you ask for and probably better than you even imagined. A great time!

19.description: Stopped in on a Friday night. Interesting place to say the least. Drinks were good. It seems like there were a lot of tall people there.  Men and women well over 6 ft. 6 in.  Nice outside patio. No roof. Perhaps that's why the tall people go there.

2.description: 52Eighty Rooftop LoungeMileNorth A Chicago Hotel166 E Superior St, 29 FlNear North SideChicago, IL 60611The place is filthy!!! Someone vomited on the floor; none of their staff even attempted to clean up when they passed by. The elevator is super slow. There are only 2 elevators.  One of them is not even working!!! When we went to the Rooftop Lounge to check out, there was one private event. So there was no spot open to the public. Guess what?!  The worse situation can happen to a woman is that when a woman is wearing the high heels, she has to walk down from 29th floor to the main lobby. I'm from Los Angeles. The 4-star rating is definitely not for this kind of place!!!! Please save your time and do not go to check out this hotel and the lounge.

18.description: Mantik was too busy refilling his mini pickle juice jar to greet us properly. My friend and I then began to talk amongst ourselves about the menu when he interrupts us aggressively by yelling "can I help you" from all the way down the bar. Let me preface all of this as WE ARE THE ONLY TWO AT THE BAR. I ask a question about the menu and he walks away, Once he returns, I then ask again about the type of beer and its hoppiness and his reply was the state it was made in- in his snarky, condescending, disrespectful and excessively loud (as in we both cringed, loud) tone. After receiving our beers, he snatched my friends card for payment and repeated three times "together?" when she had said "separate" more than once. He was stuck up and rude, especially for a bartender. Mantik (the Asian, with a bowl haircut)  is the epitome of a horrible service provider and I will never be back to this bar. Ever.  Oh and If your hungry -don't get the truffle fries at 6 bucks a pop, because we received two fries and a significant amount of crunchies left over from the fryer. The Parmesan made the scraping for burnt baby bits a tad bit worth it though. Trying to gtfo of here Update: get ready to walk 29 flights because the elevators don't work. THIS PLACE SUCKSSAVE YOUR MONEY AND GO TO CHIK FILET ON CHICAGO AVE. -Love two locals

13.description: It was pretty easy getting a couch outside on the rooftop on a Friday at 5:30 PM-- which was a relief, since the last time I tried a rooftop in Gold Coast on a weekend, it was aggravating *cough* DRUMBAR *cough*. The crowd was older than I was expecting though, and it was quieter for a Friday night than I was expecting, even after 7:00 PM. But maybe it gets rowdier later.... we ended leaving for somewhere else with more liveliness.The drinks weren't bad though--- but then again, nothing really amazing. Doesn't make my list of memorable rooftops in Chicago.

4.description: No wait to get in on a Friday night! The lounge is up on the 29th floor of Mile North Hotel, so you get a pretty nice view of some of the Chicago skyline on a clear night. There's both indoor seating and patio seating. It definitely has a modern feeling lounge to it and DJ was dropping mad beats but there's really no where really to dance. As for drinks, they have a menu of $12 cocktails which were all handcrafted. Tried the old fashioned and it was a little heavy on the simple syrup / sugar for my liking. I did notice they were serving some food & appetizers around 11pm, so definitely a bar/lounge to consider dropping by if you're looking to grab a midnight snack to go along with that cocktail.Til next time, cheers!

24.description: Came here last night. Love, love, love this place! The space is cute and cozy. They have plush seating. The staff are very friendly and prompt with services. The atmosphere is nice with lit candles, music playing, and good interactions with your guests. Oh and did i mention the view of the city is an extra bonus as well?! If you're looking for a cute, intimate space that serves good drinks and dishes, this place is recommended.

6.description: With a place that I have passed by so many times, I was always curious about this lounge. But my girlfriend and I decided on a whim and we were glad that we chose this place and it paid off big time.The ambiance and feel of the place is amazing, and the real treat is the bartender Mani, this gentleman knew his drinks, especially the Godiva lacquer chocolate drink for my lady and an especially well-made True Rob Roy straight up drink for myself. We were completely blown away from this experience and a recommended place for couples or groups for a nice, relaxing place for a drink. We have decided to make this place a frequent stop for us and welcome anyone to come to this place at 166 E. Superior St, on the 29th floor of this building. Just make sure to ask for Mani!

22.description: I came here last month for the III Gentlemen event going on at the tallest roof bar in Chicago! It was a delightful event that went super smoothly. The staff at the hotel handled the crowd beautifully. The drinks were poured strong and the bourbon selection was fantastic. Sadly, it was still a little cold and foggy so the view wasn't as vast as I'd hoped. But it just gives me a reason to go back when it's a nice day out!

15.description: Very cool ambience and beautiful view from this rooftop bar. However, the view is limited to basically one side. It is rather small so get there early if you're planning on going with a group. Drinks are a Big hit or miss, some were made right while others were All wrong!   And this was on a night when it wasn't that busy so not sure what the bartenders were doing... Definitely way way overpriced for drinks. Probably wouldn't go back only b/c there are other places you can get a beautiful rooftop view and better drinks as well for the same price.

7.description: You can probably count the number of perfect weather days we get in a Chicago summer on your fingers and toes. Well...with one of those days I totally recommend a visit to this rooftop. It's chic, has great views, comfy furniture, and an outdoor TV. Pair these features with some really tasty upscale bar snacks and you've got yourself a pretty fantastic Sunday evening out if it's not raining. And if it is you can bring the experience inside and sit at the bar which is under shelter. The food menu flaunts unique flavors including some awesome scallops, ceviche, and a foie gras peanut butter and jelly sandwich (yes, you read correct) that'll knock your socks off. The cocktail menu is small, but clever with some interesting spins on their bubbles. It's a bit pricey, but you can chalk it up as being an altitude tax. After all...everything is a little bit better at 29 floors up.

8.description: Jorge is amazing! We are out of Towner's and totally backwards in this city. He made great drinks and great suggestions for us tourists. I love the people of Chicago! So friendly and helpful. Thank you Jorge for taking the extra time for us. You kept us here for your presence alone. Much love!!

3.description: What used to be known as "C-view" has reincarnated itself as 52Eighty.  Didn't know what the old name meant and this one is just as confusing. But what hasn't changed is a great rooftop with wonderful views of the city.We went on a recent weekday night and I was surprised to find the place was not packed at 5:30 (that did change by the time we left at 7:30 so go early to get the best seats)  Plenty of comfy seating areas outside and if the weather changes (and we all know it will) there is an inside bar area as well.While the drinks were well poured, I was disappointed to learn that the menu that used to have fresh oysters on it has changed and now includes things like risotto balls, fried oysters, a loaded burger and other bar favorites.  We didn't eat, but the food at the table next to us smelled quite good so maybe change is good.Service was friendly and attentive and the staff including the manager (chef?) were very welcoming to our small group.Love that our city has so many of these great rooftop bars to enjoy the summer months!

14.description: If the Vertigo Sky Lounge is where you take your wife, 52 Eighty is where you take your mistress. This place is so cozy and quaint, very mellow but still upscale. I enjoyed the intimacy of this location off in the corner of busy downtown. I went here with my boyfriend for date night to get away from the traditional yuppie rooftop that you find elsewhere in downtown. The food was great...small plates, risotto balls, salad and a bottle of wine. The service was friendly yet casual. Low and comfy couches. We will be back.

28.description: First of all, it's a different menu than the one in Mt.Prospect. Secondly, the elderly waitress should not try to grab a customer's belonging, even just an umbrella, without asking first. The first impression of customer service was bad from the moment I walked in... then realized they don't have the same menu/dish I want... The only good thing that gives the two star is the noodles themselves (not the soup) and the cha-shu piece of meat. Even though cha-shu was good according to my friend, each piece is $2.30. The place seems to notice the price adjustment for this neighborhood, but def need more improvement on the customer service.

1.description: I'm pretty conflicted because I was expecting to like this location just as much as I like the one in Mt. Prospect. I've tried this location twice since I live so close by but I just can't give it more than a 3. Things I like: the ramen noodles are pretty darn good. They are chewy, thick and just springy enough. Also like their soft-boiled egg, bamboo shoots, and cha-shu (though I prefer the more classic ramen pork meat)Things I don't like: One of my pet peeves is ground pork in ramen. I just hate that! I'm also not a huge fan of their broths. I've tried the gold, normal, and tonkatsu and out of the three, the tonkatsu is the one I like the most but I still don't absolutely love it. I think it's missing that thick, creamy, fatty texture. All these broths are pretty salty and quite heavy for me unfortunately. There's less of a wait if you go after 7:30 or 8ish at night. Staff is quite friendly and efficient.

39.description: Having waited for months, we were so excited to see this place to open today! We did not realize it's soft open until we got there, but the owner was kind enough to let us in. Ramen was fantastic , probably the best I have had in Chicago area. Can not wait to check out the full menu on their grand open on Monday!

9.description: Originally 4 stars, but after my last visit it's dropping down to 3.Misoya is a nice addition to Streeterville, an area which already lacks solid Asian choices, let alone ramen.
