Checked it out for dinner the other day, and tried out both the Miso Ramen and the Spicy Tonkotsu Ramen. Both were solid choices, though I think I preferred the Tonkotsu simply for it's greater depth of pork flavor. My egg was perfectly soft-boiled, though that didn't hold true for all of my friends', so consistency may be an issue on that front. Nonetheless, the noodles, broth, and meat were quite good throughout. I came back again with a different group a few days later, and turns out consistency was an issue; this time the broth was much saltier and, while I am generally ok with getting hypertension, I can't say the same for everyone.They just opened, so if you want to skip the lines try coming early for dinner(5pm was a good time). Worth a try especially if you're already in the area. Being walking distance from my apartment is always a plus as well.

29.description: simple but classic. Ordered golden ramen and it tastes great.

23.description: Went for lunch with my bro. The menu is divided by the type of broth preferred gold, silver and then there's the Tokyo tonaktsu. I got the tonaktsu with added charred pork and my bro got the shrimp gold broth miso ramen. There are a whole list of items you can get as additions. We went there around 11:30 and place was pretty empty so it's a good time to go to avoid lines and to prevent feeling hurried. Now on to the food. My tonaktsu I ordered spicy, however, was pretty mild. However the broth itself was rich with pleasant hints of ginger. The noodles themselves did not seem like anything special. I do not think that the noodles are made in house. The broths do come automatically with ground pork which was a small amount. However, the added charred pork was large. My bro's ramen was less rich but also flavorful. And, per another reviewer, they definitely do not have any hot tea.  They gave me some hot water instead, which was kind of weird. Overall a solid ramen place, but Chicago has better.

5.description: The tonkotsu ramen was good! The soup was thick and not too salty. The ramen didn't come with cha-shu so we had to order it, but it was totally worth it! The only thing I didn't like was the ground pork  and the fish cake on the top. The ground pork tasted good but it was too much on the ramen. If you like ground pork, it's not a problem. However, the fish cake didn't taste like anything. The texture was not very good. Maybe they can replace it with a higher quality fish cake. In general, the ramen is good!

31.description: Not up to the standard of the Mt. Prospect location. Maybe they just need time to improve but for now there are many other better options.

25.description: This place was awesome. There were about 5 groups in front of us, and we probably waited about 15 minutes, so don't let a line dissuade you. I had the spicy tonkatsu with a slice of chashu and it was perfect. As my partner said, "spicy like nose runny, not mouth hurty," which is a pretty good description. The chashu was good, but a little thin and not as moist as I would've liked it. I probably won't order it again, and that is my only negative thought about the meal. I'm definitely planning on eating here next time I visit Chicago.

12.description: Very good ramen place! Their place is not that big (sits around 30 people) but environment is good. Ramen is amazing! You get to choose between gold and silver miso which is just the difference on how much curry paste they use and how strong the taste is. Very tasty, regardless! You can add whatever add-ons you want for an extra charge. Go with a date so it won't be boring!

37.description: Ramen is ok, but absolutely not comparable to the Ramen Misoya in Mount Prospect. Price is marked up quite a bit. Cha Shu is not very well made and the soup is definitely not boiled for 72 hours. Quality is just not on the same level as the other one. Service is poor too. Food took a while to come but the waitress brought the check pretty fast (right after we got the food), which I felt is not very appropriate. It feels like they are rushing me out of the restaurant. Overall, three stars for the brand name only. Probably won't be back again.

21.description: So I've been hearing about this ramen craze and thought, well, it is really cold. Maybe it's a sign that I should finally try it out. So on a Thursday night around 7pm I met up a girlfriend, and as an avid yelper--I failed to do my assignment and was confused on where this place was and what the outside looked like--if I had looked, there would have been no problem on locating the place. What was confusing was how we had to put our name on a list outside the restaurant-there are two doors to get in and then a waiting area that can literally fit 6 people max..I get it, were downtown Chicago and there isn't much room for such ramen shop--but man oh man-this place needs to expand.It was an unforgettable experience. My gf mentioned this was the best she has had and many of the customers there were raving about it as well. The service was nice and quick--as this is their concept setting up wooden booths (so we don't get too comfy) and smaller venue for in-out service.Only downfall is that I drove downtown to this location where it was $4 an hour with a two hour max time limit. Next time I'll be taking the public trans!

16.description: Tried this new ramen spot out in the neighborhood after they opened in December, 2015. Around 6 PM, it is a 30-minute wait or longer. There is a sign-up sheet at the vestibule door. My husband and I arrived at 6:30 and it was a 40-minute wait. Just an FYI--they will not seat a party without everyone there. Inside there are tables for fours but the waitresses don't fill them with two different couples to maximize their seating capacity so the trailing line of people are left waiting in the cold outside. They also do not serve hot tea yet. Said they just ordered it and it hasn't arrived. After a month's opening? I've never been to an Asian restaurant without hot tea to start a meal.The ramen dishes were nothing special. The broth was really salty and loaded with MSG which they can't do much about I'm told. This broth was suppose to be from their Silver Dish menu where the broth was to be "fruity and natural". It was totally "full bodied" from their Gold Dish menu side. The waitress says all their soup bases come already pre-mixed with the MSG so my face puffed up looked the moon later in the evening. Their dishes could use some bok choy, scallions, parsley, or some other greenery to add some color and fiber to their all brown dishes. I ordered the Silver Dish Hokkaido-Chasu with egg. The pork was fatty and the ground pork was very salty. My husband ordered the Silver Dish regular ramen with a fried shrimp. The dish was salty as well. Don't get me wrong, I love salt but these dishes were over loaded. What a pity as I was looking forward to getting my weekly ramen fix conveniently down the street. Service needs more training and the food could add some artistry and clearly less salt. They should also offer a no-MSG broth option. No take-outs yet.

17.description: Ate some ramen ! Wasn't bad ! I went w/ my friends, and yes I do have friends ha ha ;)I really liked the noodles ! Wow there was broth in the ramen! Ha ha :)5/5

10.description: 3.5 stars. The ramen broth here was the most notable departure from some of the other ones you see in the city. It's not tonkotsu, and it's definitely not light. It's miso based, and really thick and meaty, which may not be for everyone. The "Gold" style ramen has  thicker and saltier broth than its "Silver" counterpart. I thought the noodles were done right, and the chasu pork was also good.

11.description: Small place, very crowded and the tables are very close together. We got there around 2:30pm on a Sunday and had to wait for a table. We had to put our name on a clipboard and wait in the small space between the double doors (awkward). The server rushed us to order and we felt rushed through our meal; not sure if this is because they close at 3pm.The menu was small and the ramen wasn't anything spectacular. Chasu Ramen was pretty sub-par, looked nothing like the picture on their menu and they wanted to charge me $1.50 to make it spicy (it's an option on the menu.) Friend shrimp ramen was also subpar, nothing great. Ordered green tea and they gave us a mug of hot water with a green tea teabag on the side. It felt like a ripoff to pay $2.50 for a tea bag and hot water.Overall, it's decent if you are near by and want to get a bowl of ramen and I wouldn't make a special trip out of it or wait in line for this place.

26.description: The ramen is pretty good but not as good as Wasabi or Jinya or Ramen Takaya. The reason for the two stars is the terrible service. Although they are new and still getting used to running his place, the attitude of the place is off. They made a mistake on an order and do nothing to fix it. We asked for an ingredient on the side but instead they put it in the ramen which made it soggy. Instead of replacing it with a new batch they just brought us a plate and told us to take it out ourselves... Then I asked for the check and waited 20min and the waitress totally forgot.  Get it together!!! Your ramen is not that special for this kind of crappy service!!

27.description: I was gonna cook up some tots n eggs at home but then remembered this opened recently just down the block. Walked over on this foggy, drizzly and generally dank day and there were people waiting in the little vestibule *and* outside! There is a sign up sheet just inside said vestibule to get yourself in the queue.So it's just me and I scored a seat at the bar and reviewed the menu briefly. Got gold ramen cha shu (more body, it says, than silver, which has a clearer broth and is called "fruty" [sic] on the menu). I guess my $15.70 option is pricy owing to the 3 pieces of pork cha shu on top.It took a darn long time to get my ramen but it was pretty tasty. The broth was good, not too salty, except maybe towards the bottom. The best tasting part was the ground spicy meat (pork?) in it. Noodles were firm and didn't cloud up the broth. The pork pieces were pretty fatty and not the best tasting I've ever had. They had an uncooked pork-out-of-the-fridge twang to em. Sprouts and bamboo added crunch and some flavor. I added some fine ground white pepper to spice things up a bit.A matriarchal mama-san hustles around the place and is in her element. Other servers were friendly and even knew some Japanese. They clearly took pride in their spot.I'll give the Ramen-Nod to Oiistar and Takeya though. And pretty much any place in Asia where ramen is not such a fad like it is here. Esp. that awesome place in Hong Kong airport with some bomb-ace ramen!

35.description: We ordered silver ramen with shrimp and the spicy tonkotsu ramen. The difference between silver and gold is that gold is a slightly heavier broth than silver. I felt the silver was already quite heavy for my taste. I highly recommend adding shrimp to your ramen. That was definitely the highlight, yummy! Also, extra noodles if you're hungry. We both finished our bowls :)Not surprised that it was quite busy considering it's opening weekend, but we came half an hour before lunch ended so it wasn't too packed.

8.description: Finally a ramen place in Streeterville, where good Asian food is usually hard to find. Probably because of the higher upkeep, the storefront is not as large as the other ramen places I've been to, can maybe seat comfortably 9-10 parties of four at a time.Overall very happy with the ramen selection here. Had the Gold Cha Su Ramen; the pork pieces were tender and had just enough fat to not be too greasy. Generous portion size, and broth was very hearty if a little too salty, which I always find is an issue in ramen.The staff didn't rush us too much even when a line started to form, which was also a plus. Worth checking out if you're in the area and want a warm filling meal.

0.description: I finally got a chance to visit the new ramen shop in the city. I'm an avid fan of the Ramen Misoya location in the suburbs, so I was quite excited to hear they were opening a shop downtown. Ramen: The menu is different from the Mt. Prospect location, which was a bit disappointing to me. I got the "gold" miso and my friend got the "silver" miso. Both were good. The broth was a bit oilier than I typically prefer, potentially because the spice agents they use here are more oil based. We also got the chicken karaage, which was good.Atmosphere: The dining area is much bigger than Mt. Prospect, which means the wait was significantly less. It feels less like sitting at your grandma's house and more like a regular restaurant.Waitstaff: Friendly, nothing out of the ordinary.Overall: I enjoyed this location and still think it's the best ramen I've found downtown. However, make the trip out to Mt. Prospect if you can.

38.description: Came here around 8:30pm opening night and sat right up at the bar. Ordered a tonkotsu ramen with a spicy miso on the side. The tonkotsu came out quick and the presentation was beautiful. What we really cared about was the ramen.. and it was absolutely delicious. The broth was not too salty and the soft boiled egg was perfect. The amount of vegetables they add in to the ramen was more than I've seen in other ramen dishes and was very pleased by that. I could not stop eating ...  My favorite part was this super nice server/owner(?) came up to us to make sure our meals were good and wanted us to take home our left over ramen as we could not finish up the whole bowl (really large portions for a great price downtown $12). She told us to just boil some rice and use the broth as a soup. Delicious ramen. Great customer service. I will definitely be back here to try their other special ramens.

20.description: My husband is throwing a tantrum as I write this for giving anything less than 5 stars. But weak-stomached people be warned. You will either experience a dangerous rise in blood pressure or massive diarrhea after eating here. There is an insane amount of sodium in this ramen and it might induce a coma. Having said that, this shit is delicious and I will be eating here weekly.

19.description: Good ramen and happy to have Ramen Misoya in the neighborhood. It's not the best ramen you'll have in the City or suburbs, but it's a welcome addition. Yes, the prices are higher than they are in Mount Prospect, but that's expected because of the location and high rent costs.I've been to the Mt. Prospect location twice, the first time was the best experience food-wise. The cha-su pork was grilled to perfection. Since then, and both times at the Chicago location, the cha-su is ok, but not great. Big pieces but fatty and chewy; meat looks like it was frozen and then boiled, not grilled as it looks in the picture on the menu. No grill marks at all at this location. I won't get the cha-su again.I've now had the gold and silver cha-su ramen and I like the Gold better, although both were good. I added an extra miso egg and corn both times and enjoyed that.  I have noticed that the menu is generally different than the one in Mt. Prospect which is a bit confusing. The ramen is referred to as gold, silver or tonkatsu (spicy or regular), while in Mt. Prospect there Hokkaido Style Kome Miso, Kyoto Style Shiro Miso, Nagoya Style Mame Miso, and then there's Tokyo Style Tonkotsu spicy or regular. I assume these match up with gold, silver and then there's no third to match in Chicago. They do have the Tonkotsu which matches up.  Other than this, the options per miso variety are the same (cha-su, veggie, regular, kara-age, but no kimchi option).Other downside is no appetizers like the Mt. Prospect location. Hopefully, that will come soon (i.e. gyoza).Next time I'm in I'll go for the spicy Tonkotsu and may add some kara-age.

33.description: Tried misoya ramen for the first time. I've heard that the one in mount prospect is really good, so I was excited. The broth was great and flavorful, i ordered spicy tonkotsu ramen. Lots of goodies inside the broth, noodle was cooked perfectly. chashu was additional order and it was little disappointing since it didnt have that much flavor and wasn't really mouth melting like I expected. Still, it was one of the best ramen i've had in the states. So for that, I give 4.5 stars for the ramen (but round up to 5).

2.description: I feel bad writing a 1 star review but I had high expectations for this place. I love ramen and was excited this was opening. The noodles were okay but everything else was a disappointment. 1) Since it was new I anticipated a long wait and that didn't bother me. But there were just 2 of us and they ended up seating us at a table for 4 when it opened up. I thought that wasn't the best idea. A few minutes later they realized this and asked us to relocate to the bar seats. So we picked up our waters and awkwardly moved across the restaurant. 2) The ramen itself was pretty salty and the contents hardly resembled what I consider ramen. By the look of the other options on the menu it didn't seem like any of those were either. I'm surprised this is supposedly a successful chain in other cities.

34.description: Delicious ramen. Worth the wait! It does have a rushed feel, as others have mentioned. They give you the check before you're done eating. I think this is pretty typical of good ramen places with long lines out the door.  I only came for the food, so I don't mind that.

32.description: Ordered the Spicy Ramem, instead I got a different bowl. They end up charging me more and got the nerve to say I wasnt charged for the pepper paste. Worst customer service ever.

18.description: Delicious ramen. Worth the wait! It does have a rushed feel, as others have mentioned. They give you the check before you're done eating. I think this is pretty typical of good ramen places with long lines out the door.  I only came for the food, so I don't mind that.

13.description: I really enjoyed the ramen at Misoya. I had the Yasai ramen-gold level. The broth was delectable. Service friendly, and an overall great experience. The Yasai ramen has tons of flavor with an abundance of fresh vegetables. If you enjoy pork ramen, but also like eating an array of greens, carrots and cabbage, I highly recommend this dish!

4.description: I was gonna cook up some tots n eggs at home but then remembered this opened recently just down the block. Walked over on this foggy, drizzly and generally dank day and there were people waiting in the little vestibule *and* outside! There is a sign up sheet just inside said vestibule to get yourself in the queue.So it's just me and I scored a seat at the bar and reviewed the menu briefly. Got gold ramen cha shu (more body, it says, than silver, which has a clearer broth and is called "fruty" [sic] on the menu). I guess my $15.70 option is pricy owing to the 3 pieces of pork cha shu on top.It took a darn long time to get my ramen but it was pretty tasty. The broth was good, not too salty, except maybe towards the bottom. The best tasting part was the ground spicy meat (pork?) in it. Noodles were firm and didn't cloud up the broth. The pork pieces were pretty fatty and not the best tasting I've ever had. They had an uncooked pork-out-of-the-fridge twang to em. Sprouts and bamboo added crunch and some flavor. I added some fine ground white pepper to spice things up a bit.A matriarchal mama-san hustles around the place and is in her element. Other servers were friendly and even knew some Japanese. They clearly took pride in their spot.I'll give the Ramen-Nod to Oiistar and Takeya though. And pretty much any place in Asia where ramen is not such a fad like it is here. Esp. that awesome place in Hong Kong airport with some bomb-ace ramen!

24.description: Tried this new ramen spot out in the neighborhood after they opened in December, 2015. Around 6 PM, it is a 30-minute wait or longer. There is a sign-up sheet at the vestibule door. My husband and I arrived at 6:30 and it was a 40-minute wait. Just an FYI--they will not seat a party without everyone there. Inside there are tables for fours but the waitresses don't fill them with two different couples to maximize their seating capacity so the trailing line of people are left waiting in the cold outside. They also do not serve hot tea yet. Said they just ordered it and it hasn't arrived. After a month's opening? I've never been to an Asian restaurant without hot tea to start a meal.The ramen dishes were nothing special. The broth was really salty and loaded with MSG which they can't do much about I'm told. This broth was suppose to be from their Silver Dish menu where the broth was to be "fruity and natural". It was totally "full bodied" from their Gold Dish menu side. The waitress says all their soup bases come already pre-mixed with the MSG so my face puffed up looked the moon later in the evening. Their dishes could use some bok choy, scallions, parsley, or some other greenery to add some color and fiber to their all brown dishes. I ordered the Silver Dish Hokkaido-Chasu with egg. The pork was fatty and the ground pork was very salty. My husband ordered the Silver Dish regular ramen with a fried shrimp. The dish was salty as well. Don't get me wrong, I love salt but these dishes were over loaded. What a pity as I was looking forward to getting my weekly ramen fix conveniently down the street. Service needs more training and the food could add some artistry and clearly less salt. They should also offer a no-MSG broth option. No take-outs yet.

6.description: So I've been hearing about this ramen craze and thought, well, it is really cold. Maybe it's a sign that I should finally try it out. So on a Thursday night around 7pm I met up a girlfriend, and as an avid yelper--I failed to do my assignment and was confused on where this place was and what the outside looked like--if I had looked, there would have been no problem on locating the place. What was confusing was how we had to put our name on a list outside the restaurant-there are two doors to get in and then a waiting area that can literally fit 6 people max..I get it, were downtown Chicago and there isn't much room for such ramen shop--but man oh man-this place needs to expand.It was an unforgettable experience. My gf mentioned this was the best she has had and many of the customers there were raving about it as well. The service was nice and quick--as this is their concept setting up wooden booths (so we don't get too comfy) and smaller venue for in-out service.Only downfall is that I drove downtown to this location where it was $4 an hour with a two hour max time limit. Next time I'll be taking the public trans!

22.description: Good ramen and happy to have Ramen Misoya in the neighborhood. It's not the best ramen you'll have in the City or suburbs, but it's a welcome addition. Yes, the prices are higher than they are in Mount Prospect, but that's expected because of the location and high rent costs.I've been to the Mt. Prospect location twice, the first time was the best experience food-wise. The cha-su pork was grilled to perfection. Since then, and both times at the Chicago location, the cha-su is ok, but not great. Big pieces but fatty and chewy; meat looks like it was frozen and then boiled, not grilled as it looks in the picture on the menu. No grill marks at all at this location. I won't get the cha-su again.I've now had the gold and silver cha-su ramen and I like the Gold better, although both were good. I added an extra miso egg and corn both times and enjoyed that.  I have noticed that the menu is generally different than the one in Mt. Prospect which is a bit confusing. The ramen is referred to as gold, silver or tonkatsu (spicy or regular), while in Mt. Prospect there Hokkaido Style Kome Miso, Kyoto Style Shiro Miso, Nagoya Style Mame Miso, and then there's Tokyo Style Tonkotsu spicy or regular. I assume these match up with gold, silver and then there's no third to match in Chicago. They do have the Tonkotsu which matches up.  Other than this, the options per miso variety are the same (cha-su, veggie, regular, kara-age, but no kimchi option).Other downside is no appetizers like the Mt. Prospect location. Hopefully, that will come soon (i.e. gyoza).Next time I'm in I'll go for the spicy Tonkotsu and may add some kara-age.

15.description: I was super excited about this location because it's so close to work. Finally made it here for lunch the day after grand opening. Place was packed and I had to wait a bit for a bar seat. I got the golden miso ramen with a side of pork. It was a huge bowl with lots of goodies: tender pork, flavorful egg & bamboo shoots, crunchy bean sprouts & sweet cabbage. The broth was very strong and salty. While the ramen was good, service still had a few kinks. The kitchen was very slow: my ramen took over 30 minutes to get done, and I noticed there were several duplicate/messed up orders after me. Hopefully it's just opening jitters coz their food warrants repeat visits!

40.description: I've been to the Ramen Misoya in Mount Prospect. The Tokyo style tonkotsu ramen there was the best ramen I've ever had in Chicago area. When we knew that Ramen Misoya was going to open in downtown we were so excited! After waiting for half year they finally have a soft opening today! We can't wait to come try it tonight! The options were limited due to the soft opening. We had their famous miso ramen. Without surprise, the quality of the ramen was so good, especially the Cha Shu pork! Can't wait to try their full menu! I miss the Tokyo Tonkotsu Ramen so much! Will definitely come back!

7.description: Broth, service, and noodles were unbelievable.Chashu was sub par.Overall, arguably the best ramen in the city, definitely the best broth.(Review for Golden Miso Ramen)

36.description: I was super excited about this location because it's so close to work. Finally made it here for lunch the day after grand opening. Place was packed and I had to wait a bit for a bar seat. I got the golden miso ramen with a side of pork. It was a huge bowl with lots of goodies: tender pork, flavorful egg & bamboo shoots, crunchy bean sprouts & sweet cabbage. The broth was very strong and salty. While the ramen was good, service still had a few kinks. The kitchen was very slow: my ramen took over 30 minutes to get done, and I noticed there were several duplicate/messed up orders after me. Hopefully it's just opening jitters coz their food warrants repeat visits!

30.description: So glad this finally opened up, now we don't have to drive 50 mins out of the city for an actual bowl of ramen. Went there first week it opened with ground of 6, had to wait 20 mins due to prime time. Portions are large and loaded and quality is just as good as the burbs!

3.description: I was excited to get some ramen in Chicago, but sadly I was very disappointed with my experience at Misoya. The staff here were very questionable with their service they provided. My buddies and I ordered our ramen and the Chashu pork in their ramen was too tough and nothing like Chashu they have had at other ramen places, so they raised a complaint. To compensate, our very nice server asked us if they could provide us with something else and my friend asked for a chicken karaage replacement. The server also brought out 2 new chashu porks for them to try and see if it would taste better: and yes, it did! When it came time to pay, we discovered that the "compensation" Chicken karaage was actually charged and that it actually wasn't offered as a replacement. We then had to discuss with the manager to settle on charging them for regular ramen without Chashu and additionally adding on the chicken karaage price. I really don't see why they couldn't have just not charged us for the chicken. Oh well. They ended up losing money this way. As for the food, I personally didn't really like my Tonkotsu ramen very much, because the broth was way too salty and wasn't really very tasty. The egg was great and the noodles were very chewy, which I loved, but the broth really ruined the whole thing for me. I am sad to say that I will not be coming to a Misoya Ramen again.

14.description: So glad this finally opened up, now we don't have to drive 50 mins out of the city for an actual bowl of ramen. Went there first week it opened with ground of 6, had to wait 20 mins due to prime time. Portions are large and loaded and quality is just as good as the burbs!

1.description: For those of us who spend many hours every day inside of the Lurie Research Center, Zebi is our one option for food and drinks.  I must say they have a pretty vast assortment of snacks from fresh fruits to protein bars, chips, yogurt parfaits, hummus, etc.  They do have hot items as well as a salad bar, although I haven't tried any of those items.  I usually stop at Zebi for my hot drip coffee; I have tried their espresso drinks and am not impressed, the latte just does not do it for me.  Zebi is a good option if you don't want to leave Lurie, but I would venture elsewhere if I had time to do so.

2.description: Located in the Lurie Research Center at Northwestern University. There is a small selection of food options, and they have a salad bar with a decent amount of choices. The coffee here is ok; I tend to settle for it because I'm not really picky about my coffee and I don't like to walk elsewhere. They also have a selection of fresh fruit, but the quality isn't the greatest. I'd say the best thing that Zebi has to offer are their breakfast sandwiches, which come in normal and healthy varieties.

0.description: Zebi took over this small location behind Lurie auditorium a few months back - and it's a big improvement. The breakfast sandwiches are custom-made however you want, rather than just pulled out of a package and heated - like they do at Starbucks. They've got muffins, cold drinks, several coffee options, and lots of quick bites to choose from. I still go to Starbucks across the street for my coffee though. But I come to Zebi for food during class. I just wish they opened at 8 instead of 9.

58.description: I visited w/friends (11/12/15). Gino's East always delicious. We ordered a large deep dish pizza w/cheese & patty sausage. YesThis patty sausage covers the pizza pan,Atop a buttery cornmeal/flour crust. Then Fresh Mozzarella cheese & topped w/fresh thick tomato sauce. See photo.Baked perfectly & served warm tableside.Good customer service.

56.description: My sister and I sat at the bar a few weeks ago and were very disappointed. The bartenders working were clearly dating. The guy kept fighting with the girl about "flirting" with people at the bar. It was ridiculous. As if that wasn't annoying enough, one of the managers kept coming back there and gossiping about other bartenders and saying how she couldn't wait to get rid of them. The whole thing was just very unprofessional and odd. I think that behavior like this should be kept behind the scenes. On a brighter note, the pizza was good, but be prepared to wait....

29.description: This place is truly amazing!!! You here the hips and are like, "I'll try it" but nobody is BS' Inga you, THIS IS THE REAL DEAL!!! I had the wings to start and they were some of the best I've ever had, they were perfect.  The jalapeño blue pizza I had was exquisite, no other word does it justice. The food takes awhile to come out but good things come to those who wait.Go here, don't think, just go!!

42.description: For all of us New Yorkers, I will stand by our pizza, and our beliefs... But here's the deal if you are in chi-town, a lot of awful deep dish floods the city, and this is truly why New York pizza is [obviously] better.But when in town, you really must hit Gino's east.   It's the best I've had in town, and it actually is pretty awesome!Order what I did, the entire bottom layer will be one big, delicious, homemade sausage patty, covered in cheese and sauce and man is it heaven.   This is like pizza soup, so understand that and don't expect what you're used to if you're a New Yorker.  Also, don't even judge if you're from the carolinas or something, I know you guys just eat Pizza Hut and have wet dreams.Check Gino's out now! But keep in mind it's all fresh cooked and it's like baking a pie, you will have to wait.   I say at the bar and had a blast chatting with the staff and others in the bar.

23.description: The deep dish pizza is Devine and worth the wait!  The wait staff is very cordial and the atmosphere is funky and fun

47.description: Good thing that when we stumbled upon The Original Gino's East of Chicago that we were not hungry.  We had just eaten our lunch about 2 hours prior.  I told my wife that had to try Chicago style deep dish pizza from here because it was on my wish list!  She was all for making me happy!Wow, we waited almost 2 hours before we finally ate our pizza!!  The wait starts outside the front entrance.  15 minute wait outside.  After letting us in the door, another 15 minute wait at the hostess station.  Then have a seat on their long couch and waited another 15 minutes before being led upstairs to our table.  After placing our order, it took about 45 minutes for our pizza to arrive.  Chicago Deep Style pizza does take awhile to prepare so we were not surprised.  So, was it worth the long wait???  Oh yeah, it sure was!!    We ordered the smallest size of their Meaty Legend for us to share.  It was our very first time trying Chicago Style Deep Dish pizza anywhere.  Talk about huge!  No wonder you need a fork and knife to eat these pizzas.  It was loaded with pepperoni, Italian sausage, Canadian bacon, and bacon!  Very flavorful pizza.  The crust was unlike any other as well.Even with the very long wait, it was so worth the experience!  Would come here again if only to see if my wife's signature is still there!  So cool that anyone can write their name almost anywhere in the restaurant.  Part of the charm of the place.  Make sure you do not come too hungry cause you are in for a loooong wait!

8.description: I decided to eat at Gino's East for my last meal in Chicago before going back to the airport. We hailed a cab to the original Gino's. We got there when they were just opening so there were  no huge lines. There is like graffiti everywhere it reminded me of the inside of a Chronic Tacos minus the skate stickers.  We decided to split a pepperoni  and sausage deep dish with some mozzarella sticks to start. We didn't mind eating heavy because we had a long trip ahead of us. I didn't believe it when someone told me that the pizza at Gino's is light compared to their competitors . It was much lighter than Lou Malnatis. The crust was light even though it was thick ....delicious ! I didn't feel like falling asleep after the meal so that is another plus! There are a lot of celebrity pictures up but a lot of them have graffiti on them. Management should make a rule not to write on the photos because there were some I couldn't even make out. It was a shame because I like looking at that type of stuff just to see who else ate at Ginos. It was a good experience at least when I'm writing reviews of deep dish pizzas in other cities I will know what an authentic deep dish tastes like!

31.description: Pizza is the the best in all of Chicago every time I'm in town I make sure to stop in a order a pizza or 2....

34.description: Fried ravioli appetizer.Mighty meat pizza. Found this to be the best Chicago style pizza while in town. UNOs was trash. Lou Malnatti's has less of sauce and chunks of tomato, I would say the pizza wasn't bad  but......not my style. I prefer the crisp & deep dish crunch of Geno's, with flavorful sauce in between layers of cheese and toppings. If you are a first timer just know it takes 45 minutes to an hour to bake....so get an appetizer if you're starving!

16.description: For all of us New Yorkers, I will stand by our pizza, and our beliefs... But here's the deal if you are in chi-town, a lot of awful deep dish floods the city, and this is truly why New York pizza is [obviously] better.But when in town, you really must hit Gino's east.   It's the best I've had in town, and it actually is pretty awesome!Order what I did, the entire bottom layer will be one big, delicious, homemade sausage patty, covered in cheese and sauce and man is it heaven.   This is like pizza soup, so understand that and don't expect what you're used to if you're a New Yorker.  Also, don't even judge if you're from the carolinas or something, I know you guys just eat Pizza Hut and have wet dreams.Check Gino's out now! But keep in mind it's all fresh cooked and it's like baking a pie, you will have to wait.   I say at the bar and had a blast chatting with the staff and others in the bar.

13.description: My first time in Chicago and I've has countless amount of friends tell me that I HAVE to try Gino's Pizza. Being right down the street from my hotel it's only fitting that I try it.I came in at around 5:05 and it wasn't busy. I was scared because I've heard of the crazy wait but I guess it just depends when you go. They walked me upstairs, the place is cool, the walls are tagged and it just has this warm feeling. My server comes to my table and asks if I want anything, and before anything lets me know that the deep dish pizza will take 46-60 to make! So here I am thinking well if it takes that long, it must be good!? I get the fried mozzarella. And it came out right away. It was deliciously crispy. I wish it was hotter, the cheese was very chewy and I was hoping for a more "melt in your mouth" experience. Definitely don't go alone, or without something to do because the wait for your dish is no joke. My dish came out and it looks small but it is so filling! I only had two slices out of the 4. I'm stuffed with so much cheese. The thickness of the cheese is greater than the dough. The dough itself wasn't that great. It tasted wierd and usually I love the crust. Not this one. The sauce was delicious and I got pepperoni as well. It was really really good. I'm glad I tried it because we don't have Deep-Dish Pizzas in Los Angeles

11.description: Was in Chicago for a staff meeting and one of my coworkers was born and raised in Chicago.  For our first dinner, she recommended Gino's.  When we got there, it was a Tuesday night around 6:00pm so it wasn't too crowded and there was no wait. I started with the refreshing Ace Perry Hard Cider - It was so good.  Not too sweet, cool and refreshing with a nice hint of pear.Harvest Salad (Spinach, Field Greens, Dried Cranberries, Candied Walnuts, Crumbled Blue Cheese, Rasberry Vinaigrette) - I'm not a big salad fan but all the ingredients went well together. Gino's Family Platter (Spinach Sticks, Mozzarella Sticks, Fried Calamari, Spinach artichoke Dip, toasted crostini). - It was OK, too much grease.Large Gino's supreme - It was yummy.  I loved everything with all the gooey cheese and the big chunks of juicy tomatoes.  Don't know if I will ever go back to Chicago but I will go to Gino's again.

39.description: This was my first "original" Chicago-style pizza in Chi-town. Over the years, I've gravitated towards thin crust pizzas. So this was my first deep dish in YEARS. Three full sized adults men shared a medium deep dish "Meaty Legend."  It took about 45 minutes to cook. No surprise there since it's a deep dish. The crust was extremely buttery and breakaway. The meats blended well together. Mmmmmm so good, but so heavy. We all had two slices but we're stuffed. Along with it, I had a bottled beer (5 Vulture). Luckily I decided not to go with a second. I finished it before the pizza came out and wouldn't have had the appetite to help kill the pizza. Is recommend it to get your Chicago deep dish fix.

37.description: Someone recommended we try this over our usual Lou Malnati's, big mistake. It isn't nearly as good. Not even close. The crust here is too sweet and has an odd consistency. It reminds me of cornbread. We had tons of appetizers and all of them were ok at best. The nachos were especially horrible.

0.description: I was staying in Chicago, so I had to right?First off, the atmosphere here is great. The crowd is upbeat and the design of the place is really cool with writing all over the walls. I tried a few of the pizzas as I was with a large group, and they were all really good. My favorite was the Chicago Fire. The deep dish is definitely not what I'm used to being from Jersey. Be aware that these things take a while to cook, so get some drinks and appetizers while you're waiting (but not too many appetizers, these pies are filling). If you're exploring some real Chicago deep dish pizza options, add Gino's to the list.

38.description: My first experience with fresh, Chicago-style deep dish did not disappoint! Gino's has a light, flaky crust, lots of cheese, high quality toppings, and just the right amount of sauce.Prices were a bit steep, but well worth it for the quality of the finished product.

51.description: Well after waiting 20 min for drinks we ordered right away. 30 min later my so called thin crust pizza came out. The pizza was cold, so they took it back and put it in the oven.... First of all thin crust is supposed to be THIN... This crust was regular, and the crust was doughy... Not a good start to my "Chicago Pizza" experience. I had better Chicago Thin crust in Las Vegas...

27.description: I adore Gino's East pizza but we moved away so I was beyond thrilled to get to have it on our Christmas trip back to Chicago. We were used to the Wheaton location where you can order the lunch special at your tables. We saw the sign for the lunch special as we were waiting and wanted to do that but our waiter said you have to sit in a special place for that so we couldn't do it. He also said all those mini pizzas are pre-baked early in the morning and wouldn't be that good. We were bummed and surprised and didn't see any of that info posted anywhere. We ended up spending a ton more money than expected. Beers are $9 each and a basic salad is $7. Our server was complaining that he was working 24 hours in 2 days. It just wasn't as great of an experience as we had hoped. The pizza was good but soggy. We'll stick to other locations in the future!

32.description: Service was slow in the initial greeting and delivery of drinks.  Appetizers were served quickly.  One of the orders was totally messed up and a totally different order was served.  Deep Dish Pizza was fantastic.  Sandwich was ok.  Server was apologetic about the problem and took care of it by taking it off the ticket.  Great atmosphere but be prepared to wait.

54.description: Out of all the deep dish pizzas I tried in Chicago this was my favorite. The crust was amazing and the pizza was very flavorful. I had the veggie and I was not disappointed. The cheese to sauce ratio was perfect. Also the pizza comes in a cast iron dish, which was unique since all other places brought in the aluminum pan. Visit Gino's if you're in Chicago! You won't be disappointed!

48.description: My wife and I ordered the Meaty Legend. It was easily the best pizza I have ever had! The wait wasn't too long when we went on Saturday night, but the pizzas take an hour to bake. For such a simple pizza, everything from the meat to the cheese and crust were beyond compare to any pizza chain.

44.description: My favorite place to get Deep Dish Pizza! Every time my family comes to Chicago we have to go here and get some of the spinach deep dish pizza. It's really heavy food, but that's what you should be expecting with deep dish pizza in general. I'm pretty sure the crust is made out of cornbread which gives the whole pizza a more complex, interesting flavor overall. My favorite deep dish joint :)

24.description: Sorry to say, coming in first isn't always the best thing.Although Gino's was the first to create the deep dish, it didn't perfect it.Our wait to be seated was around 15 minutes for a party of 2.  Once we put in our order, the small supreme deep dish took an hour to come out.  Which the server had advised and we had ordered a bowl of chili to preoccupy us during the wait.  When we got the pizza, it wasn't very hot.  Felt like it was sitting out for a while... especially considering that we had ordered in from Lou Malnati's and even with delay, the pizza was hotter than the pizza at Gino's.Pizza, itself, was still edible with lots of cheese, but what it falls short on is the crust.  I hate crusts in general, but it's bearable in Lou Malnati's because it's buttery and crispy.  Here it was just plain dry.  Also the sauce was just too watery.  Felt like eating an oven-baked pizza from a super market.  Don't waste your time waiting here...Also, all the graffiti around the walls and tables just looked tacky and gross.  I understand that they want to look vintage, but it just looks dirty and grimy.

7.description: Very good pizza! Seemed to get prepared a little faster than the location on Lasalle. I always order the Chicago Fire. Thank god for the Groupon that I received. It was nice to only pay half of what I would have paid for the amount of pizza I received.I wish that the staff here were personable. They were not bad. But they did not really go above and beyond to provide outstanding customer service. This would be fine, except, tourists are aware that this is a Chicago staple. So you'd think that they would want to go all out with their servers' service delivery. For the location, on a Tuesday night, I walked right in and got a booth at 6:30 in the evening. Score!The deep dish pie was so much better than I remembered at my first experience with Gino's on Lasalle. This sausage is absolutely outstanding. The onions were sauteed perfectly! Not too soft but not hard - the perfect amount of crunch. It was the perfect amount of spice to it as well. All in all a wonderful experience!One last thing. The mens bathroom here was disgusting. So this paired with the decent customer service is what knocked it down from a 4.5 star experience to a 4 star experience.

49.description: Great location and great pizza! Love the uniqueness of the decor. We ordered 4 different pizzas for our group and all were fantastic. Definitely worth the wait!

40.description: Oh my yummmm! Had pizza from here some months ago and I'm still thinking about it! The slices were nice and big. I'm not a small person and one really gets you satisfied, but you force yourself to eat two because it's just that good. Hearty meal.

53.description: Best darn pizza I have ever had. Great meatballs as well. Try the meaty legend! De-lish-ous! Mmmmmm

30.description: Ate here on 12/23.  Kids loved the pasta and marinara sauce which was a reasonably priced portion.   If you want deep dish, leave an hour for making the pizza as we didn't and that is what we really wanted but were warned that our tight schedule would make it though to get.  The thin crust veggie was good but nothing worth going out of your way.  Atmosphere is loud and tv's around for entertainment if you so desire.  Good meal and fair price but may have given a better rating if we were able to get the deep dish we wanted.

46.description: Our hour wait for the pizza was well worth it!!!  Definitely coming  back again next time in the Windy City!!

1.description: As a Chicago landmark,  I had to stop by. Especially since my hotel was around the corner. This was my first experience with Chicago deep dish pizza.  Let me say the pizza was very good. Lots of flavor. I wasn't a big fan of the crust here, but it didn't take away too much from the overall experience. As far as the actual restaurant, the place is great. Friendly staff. Cool art on wall. Plenty of TVs. Worth a sit down.

55.description: In Streeterville, if you are on the go and want to have something good while saving a few bucks, come here.  Their carry-out lunch special cannot be beat.  A mini-deep dish, a salad or soup, and a drink, with tax, $6.91!

9.description: I was so excited to go here, but sadly, it was not an experience that blew me away.  In fact, upon leaving, me and the other person in my party both expressed mutual disappointment.  It was probably around 2 or 2:30pm on Veteran's Day that I was here.  Wasn't crowded at all.  We were going to partake in the lunch special but it was presented to us as being more of a "carry out" type of thing rather than a sit down, order and eat.  The Lou Malnati's lunch special is awesome and can be ordered as non carry out.  Oh, I tried "Not Your Father's Root Beer" here for the first time.  It was good, but a LOT to drink.  I need to start doing more shots.  More compact volume of liquid.  So, about the pizza...  We ordered a small cheese.  Deep dish.  It was okay.  It wasn't bad.  There was something "off" about the sauce, according to my tastebuds, but I didn't gag on it or spit it out in disgust.  I also didn't like the crust as much as Lou's.  I definitely ate my full slice and a half.  I wouldn't allow myself a full two pieces.  My personal mainstream deep dish pizza ranking is as follows:Best: Lou Malnati'sThen: Giordano'sThen: Gino'sI loved the decor and feel of the place, so there's that.

26.description: I am from Detroit,  and thus gas to be the best Chicago style deep dish pizza. How could it not? You wait 2 hours for a table,  3 minutes to order,  and 1 hour for the pizza to bake.  Perfect every time.  This location is huge, there must serve thousands every day.  The spinach and cheese sticks are great, as is the bacon be Brussel spouts.

25.description: So disappointed that they took our favorite pizza off the menu---BBQ chicken thin-crust.  It's been our favorite for several years.  We built our own thin crust mushroom, and it was good; however, I am not happy that they don't offer the BBQ chicken anymore.  Cheesy pizza bread was tasty, but it's a rather skimpy portion.  Good beer selection, but a bit pricey.  Our server was excellent.

12.description: Awesome memories of my first trip to Chicago 9 yrs ago ushered me back to this first place I experienced Chicago deep dish. Hello again Gino's. S'been a while. Why, thank you; you haven't aged either. I remember being blown away by the pizza and calamari, so to validate the high regard I've held for this place ever since, ordered the same.  The calamari was incredible. The crispy seasoned coating was so perfect I just stopped & stared after every bite, which worked out convenient since it takes nearly 30min for them to make your pizza. I'm a slow eater -which infuriates everyone I dine with- but this time, the wait granted me a pass.Then, it arrived. My awesome waitress plated the first slice and then insisted on awaiting my approbation. She stood there beaming but silent, as if a sacred rite had begun. I took a bite. My soul cried out in ecstacy. Seeing my face, my waitress smiled and departed.I had forgotten how much darn cheese they stuff them with, so after the 3rd slice found myself overwhelmed. Everything else was as fresh and remarkable as I remember. Way to hold the crown Gino's.

59.description: So good. Went in with my mom. Took about 30 min for the deep dish to come out. very fast service.

21.description: Very good pizza! Seemed to get prepared a little faster than the location on Lasalle. I always order the Chicago Fire. Thank god for the Groupon that I received. It was nice to only pay half of what I would have paid for the amount of pizza I received.I wish that the staff here were personable. They were not bad. But they did not really go above and beyond to provide outstanding customer service. This would be fine, except, tourists are aware that this is a Chicago staple. So you'd think that they would want to go all out with their servers' service delivery. For the location, on a Tuesday night, I walked right in and got a booth at 6:30 in the evening. Score!The deep dish pie was so much better than I remembered at my first experience with Gino's on Lasalle. This sausage is absolutely outstanding. The onions were sauteed perfectly! Not too soft but not hard - the perfect amount of crunch. It was the perfect amount of spice to it as well. All in all a wonderful experience!One last thing. The mens bathroom here was disgusting. So this paired with the decent customer service is what knocked it down from a 4.5 star experience to a 4 star experience.

17.description: To each their own. The pizza tastes just fine, but I would go with Pequod's or Giordano's over Gino's. Their pizza cost slightly more, but doesn't taste as good. The ambiance is very inviting and laid back. Graffiti all over the walls, TVs everywhere (huge projector), and a full bar for those who drink. Their were families their, couples, college students etc etc. The service is outstanding. We requested our checks and boxes as soon as we got our pizza because we didn't want to wait around. When we got our check, they accidentally charged us for an extra topping and the waiter fixed it right away. Nice attentive waiters. This is located near magnificent mile, so parking is tough and expensive. We walked from North Ave Beach which took about 22 minutes at a slow pace. You get to enjoy the lake and it feels awesome on a nice night.

10.description: While doing my research for good deep dish pizza in Chicago, I kept reading about Lou Malnati's and Giordano's (and Pequod's, which I didn't get to try). I didn't even hear about Gino's East until my boyfriend found it while looking for deep dish places. Well, I'm glad he found it because we both really liked it. (this was my second fave after Giordano's and before Lou's, but it was his fave overall).What makes Gino's different than the ones we tried is that they have unique toppings. It seems that a lot of places like to stick to the "classics", like sausage, peppers, onions, pepperoni, etc., you know the drill. But Gino's is not afraid to step outside the box. They've got pizzas like the Jalapeño blue (bacon, blue cheese, Italian sausage, blue cheese & bacon stuffed jalapeños) and the Chi-talian Stallion (Italian beef, roasted sweet peppers, giardiniera).We did half and half of the aforementioned pizzas. I didn't really taste much sausage in the jalapeño blue, but I did taste the blue cheese and jalapeños. I liked the Chi-talian Stallion better (which was the one I picked) because I just really like giardiniera. Plus, chopped beef??? What's not to like?!If you want something other than a boring classic deep dish, you should definitely try out Gino's East.

5.description: I am from Detroit,  and thus gas to be the best Chicago style deep dish pizza. How could it not? You wait 2 hours for a table,  3 minutes to order,  and 1 hour for the pizza to bake.  Perfect every time.  This location is huge, there must serve thousands every day.  The spinach and cheese sticks are great, as is the bacon be Brussel spouts.

3.description: Sorry to say, coming in first isn't always the best thing.Although Gino's was the first to create the deep dish, it didn't perfect it.Our wait to be seated was around 15 minutes for a party of 2.  Once we put in our order, the small supreme deep dish took an hour to come out.  Which the server had advised and we had ordered a bowl of chili to preoccupy us during the wait.  When we got the pizza, it wasn't very hot.  Felt like it was sitting out for a while... especially considering that we had ordered in from Lou Malnati's and even with delay, the pizza was hotter than the pizza at Gino's.Pizza, itself, was still edible with lots of cheese, but what it falls short on is the crust.  I hate crusts in general, but it's bearable in Lou Malnati's because it's buttery and crispy.  Here it was just plain dry.  Also the sauce was just too watery.  Felt like eating an oven-baked pizza from a super market.  Don't waste your time waiting here...Also, all the graffiti around the walls and tables just looked tacky and gross.  I understand that they want to look vintage, but it just looks dirty and grimy.

35.description: We stayed here's for 2 weeks and went to this place Twice since it's next door from the hotel we stayed at. I love pizza but every time we went the service got worse. The glass of champagne I had was flat, tables are dirty and servers don't seem to care. I asked the hostess were the restroom was while he was talking to the other female hostess. He acted like I was interrupteing his game while trying to pick up on a girl. I almost asked for the manager but realized no one really cares at this place. The lines are long and service is very poor for all the hipe. Typical of a restaurant that always have  bunch of new people on vacation lined up to try. Would not recommend.

19.description: Third stop in my Chicago pizza tour.Another iconic Chicago pizza joint.Long lines, I ordered ahead and took it to go. Takes 45 minutes to make so time yourself.Gino's Supreme - $28 - Thick buttery crust. Loaded with sausage, pepperoni, and peppers. Red sauce was not as good as Lou's. Still a great pizza.

28.description: I was so excited to go here, but sadly, it was not an experience that blew me away.  In fact, upon leaving, me and the other person in my party both expressed mutual disappointment.  It was probably around 2 or 2:30pm on Veteran's Day that I was here.  Wasn't crowded at all.  We were going to partake in the lunch special but it was presented to us as being more of a "carry out" type of thing rather than a sit down, order and eat.  The Lou Malnati's lunch special is awesome and can be ordered as non carry out.  Oh, I tried "Not Your Father's Root Beer" here for the first time.  It was good, but a LOT to drink.  I need to start doing more shots.  More compact volume of liquid.  So, about the pizza...  We ordered a small cheese.  Deep dish.  It was okay.  It wasn't bad.  There was something "off" about the sauce, according to my tastebuds, but I didn't gag on it or spit it out in disgust.  I also didn't like the crust as much as Lou's.  I definitely ate my full slice and a half.  I wouldn't allow myself a full two pieces.  My personal mainstream deep dish pizza ranking is as follows:Best: Lou Malnati'sThen: Giordano'sThen: Gino'sI loved the decor and feel of the place, so there's that.

45.description: There was a huge wait of up to 2hrs... Just to get in.The pizza itself took 1 hour and it wasn't worth the wait...The cheese was rubbery and there was a ton of sauce...I have heard that this place has seated celebrities

33.description: My first time in Chicago and I've has countless amount of friends tell me that I HAVE to try Gino's Pizza. Being right down the street from my hotel it's only fitting that I try it.I came in at around 5:05 and it wasn't busy. I was scared because I've heard of the crazy wait but I guess it just depends when you go. They walked me upstairs, the place is cool, the walls are tagged and it just has this warm feeling. My server comes to my table and asks if I want anything, and before anything lets me know that the deep dish pizza will take 46-60 to make! So here I am thinking well if it takes that long, it must be good!? I get the fried mozzarella. And it came out right away. It was deliciously crispy. I wish it was hotter, the cheese was very chewy and I was hoping for a more "melt in your mouth" experience. Definitely don't go alone, or without something to do because the wait for your dish is no joke. My dish came out and it looks small but it is so filling! I only had two slices out of the 4. I'm stuffed with so much cheese. The thickness of the cheese is greater than the dough. The dough itself wasn't that great. It tasted wierd and usually I love the crust. Not this one. The sauce was delicious and I got pepperoni as well. It was really really good. I'm glad I tried it because we don't have Deep-Dish Pizzas in Los Angeles

43.description: I was introduced to this establishment while on a Bobby's Bike Hike bike tour, and followed up by ordering a take out deep dish sausage pie a few days later.  Having grown up in NJ, I think I'll always be more of a thin crust/brick oven type of person, but if there's any place that will convince me otherwise, it would be Gino's East.  Having eaten at Malnati's and Giordano's, I think Gino's is the best of the bunch.  I love the sausage, their take on the cornmeal crust, and the overall feel of this old-school place, although I have yet to really dine there.  I hope to remedy this very soon!

2.description: COCKROACH AT OUR TABLE Bus boy took care of it quickly and calmly but still not a good start to dinner..before we even order.Waitress was not good either, was always rushing away before anything could be asked.

18.description: For being one of the most famous pizza joints in Chicago, I have to say I was slightly disappointed. The best part of the pizza I would say is the crust. It was golden brown, light, and flaky. We ordered the Gino's Supreme and it was a decent pizza. The ingredients and sauce definitely tasted fresh.  The reason I say I was disappointed is because the pizza wasn't "blow your mind" amazing. It was just a decent pie. Also, it was a very pricey pizza. The service and ambiance were great. Our server was attentive, kind, and catered to every need we had. I did enjoy the ambiance a lot, the graffiti on the walls accompanied by the large TVs gave it a modern and fun feel while the candlelights mimicked a date like experience. Personally, I would rank this in third behind Lous and Pequods and followed by Giordanos. If you haven't tried Gino's, I would suggest it so you can formulate your own opinion, just don't expect a life changing experience!

41.description: I was here for the night and my friend and I decided we wanted local pizza.  We asked a local girl which place was better Gino's East or Giordanos and she said between the two Gino's is better.  So we went to Gino's.  We both had a thin crust pizza and found it to be similar to a frozen pizza from the grocery store.  Not much taste at all and for $20.00 it should be really tasty.. and a lot bigger than 12".  I won't return to Gino's.  I can find better pizza in Florida.

52.description: My first deep dish pizza ever, so I had to try one at the original Chicago Deep dish...it was good.  Options were plentiful, seating was ok with about a 20 minute wait for a table, then an hour wait while the pizza baked.  It was good but I'll stick with my thin slice

50.description: We come every year to Chicago at this time of year. It's been a 15 year tradition. The last two years we've picked up pizza at Gino's. It's so good. One of the highlights of our trip. It's a new tradition.

4.description: Really enjoyed the vibe of this restaurant. Was here on vacay and wanted to get a second round of deep dish (first was Giordano's). And Gino's was close by so why not. The pizza wait time was around 40 mins. It was well worth it. It was totally different than Giordanos (ie. Less of a pie more of a pizza). Overall, the cheese and sauce were pretty delicious but didn't feel as unique to me as Giordano's. Though if you're on vacay like I was, it's worth a try.

6.description: My wife and I got the Deep Dish Nachos appetizer ($11) and Jalapeño Blue deep dish pizza ($25).  The nachos can only be described as holy cheese!  Very cheesy, super tasty.  The presentation wasn't all that fancy, but who cares about that?  This isn't an upscale place, the atmosphere is very laid back and down to earth and the taste of the pizza is MIND BLOWING!  My only regret is that I won't be able to sample the whole menu since I'm only in town a couple of days.Now I'm not going to lie to you, if you're looking for some great pizza quick you will not find it here.  The deep dish pizzas take 45 minutes to cook and they are well worth the wait time.  So grab some friends, grab some drinks and relax and make conversation for a bit.  Overall we were there for about an hour and 15 minutes give or take.And as a side note, the beer is pretty tasty too.  Prices are reasonable for draght (20oz for $8) and they've got a good selection of local brews for anyone from out of town looking to sample the Chicago fare.And side side note, they also do a military discount.  I can't complain!

22.description: Good pizza; however not the best in Chicago. I would highly recommend Giordano's is located across the street. Crust is better I think; however Giordano's has a much better sauce which, for me, is why I think it is better. They're pizza is not bad by any means; but definitely not the best in Chicago.

15.description: Good thing that when we stumbled upon The Original Gino's East of Chicago that we were not hungry.  We had just eaten our lunch about 2 hours prior.  I told my wife that had to try Chicago style deep dish pizza from here because it was on my wish list!  She was all for making me happy!Wow, we waited almost 2 hours before we finally ate our pizza!!  The wait starts outside the front entrance.  15 minute wait outside.  After letting us in the door, another 15 minute wait at the hostess station.  Then have a seat on their long couch and waited another 15 minutes before being led upstairs to our table.  After placing our order, it took about 45 minutes for our pizza to arrive.  Chicago Deep Style pizza does take awhile to prepare so we were not surprised.  So, was it worth the long wait???  Oh yeah, it sure was!!    We ordered the smallest size of their Meaty Legend for us to share.  It was our very first time trying Chicago Style Deep Dish pizza anywhere.  Talk about huge!  No wonder you need a fork and knife to eat these pizzas.  It was loaded with pepperoni, Italian sausage, Canadian bacon, and bacon!  Very flavorful pizza.  The crust was unlike any other as well.Even with the very long wait, it was so worth the experience!  Would come here again if only to see if my wife's signature is still there!  So cool that anyone can write their name almost anywhere in the restaurant.  Part of the charm of the place.  Make sure you do not come too hungry cause you are in for a loooong wait!

57.description: Visited with colleagues on a Thursday, late afternoon. Since the pizzas we're going to take a long time we ordered fried artichoke hearts and artichoke dips. Both delicious. Once the pizzas arrived--be prepared to wait--they proved to be well worth the wait. Had my favorite pizza with pineapples and hamburgers. Too die for! The graffiti on the walls and chairs are fascinating. The music can stand to be turned down some. But overall a great experience.

20.description: So, a tourist in Chicago, of course we had to eat at Gino's.  I love me some deep dish.  It was awesome.  Of course, you have to wait.  We waited 30 min for a table, then about 45 min for our deep dish pizza.  So much food.  The sausage and tomato sauce and all the gooey cheese was outstanding. I am not a small guy but I could only eat two slices, and the second one was a chore to finish.  Each slice must be 2000 calories, but well worth it.  A must.

36.description: Gino's is always a must when we come to Chicago. We were in town on Saturday. Gino's did not disappoint, great service and fabulous food. Our appetizers and deep dish pizza were amazing. Can't wait till our next visit.

14.description: The restaurant and staff felt really welcoming and the atmosphere is rocky-pleasant (sorry new world!). The pizzas ARE really that good. Minus for the wait and the fact that I prefer thin pizza crust!
